PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister, in light of the appalling escalation of organised crime: Is it a fact that the Minister for Administrative Services and the Attorney-General have repeatedly rejected my persistent calls over the past three years for a national crimes commission? Is it also a fact that the Prime Minister's Government is reluctant to agree to my proposal, as set out in the Notice Paper, to set up a Federal-State crimes commission? Has his attention been drawn to today's Press article relating to the setting up of such a commission? Will he take immediate steps to set up, preferably, a national crimes commission? If that is still not acceptable, will he set up, with the co- operation of the States, a Federal-State commission? Finally, will he give an assurance that any such commission will be given adequate powers to subpoena witnesses and evidence and, as well, adequate investigative powers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened with the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking goes some way towards the establishment of what might loosely be called a Federal or national crimes commission. It is an example of governments of the Commonwealth and the States working very closely together for purposes which I am sure all honourable members in this House, indeed everyone, would want to support. The Joint Task Force is another example of the kind of co-operation which has developed in more recent times because of a growing concern by governments and communities at the development and growth of crime involving high finance, drugs and whatever else people like to name. I think the time has come when we have to question whether the conventional means of law enforcement, as known in the past, are adequate to deal with the circumstances that we have to face at the present time.

ANSWER.PARA: In some senses the two joint royal commissions that have been established can be regarded as an experiment which could well lead to the establishment of a national crimes commission, but the Attorney-General and other Ministers are examining this and papers will come before the Government so that we can make a considered judgment about it in the not too distant future. In these objectives obviously one would hope to have the co-operation of the States. For a long while the States have regarded law enforcement in many areas as a close preserve of their own and have not relished the development of the Australian Federal Police or the growing involvement of the Commonwealth in areas of law enforcement, but necessarily, because of the nature of Commonwealth law and of crimes that are committed in the modern world, there has been a growing Commonwealth involvement. I suspect that that is likely to continue.

If there were a national crimes commission, there may be three areas that one would need to examine. Obviously one is the maintenance and enforcement of Commonwealth laws as they are. That in itself would give the commission very considerable power and would give it a very considerable field in which to operate. One would hope to be able to establish such a body in co-operation with the States so that it would be a joint body. One would hope also that such a body would be able to make recommendations on where changes of the law might be desirable as a result of its own findings. I believe that if the Commonwealth were to wait until it had the total agreement of all States, through either the Premiers Conference or the Attorneys-General, the youngest members here might be grey with age before that would be achieved. I do not really believe that as a nation we have time for that.

It needs to be understood that a national crimes commission-as the words are loosely used-would in many ways have the powers of a standing royal commission. I mentioned earlier that what is happening with the joint royal commissions is in a sense a precursor-an experiment-which could well lead to the development of a national crimes commission. When the Government made the decisions to establish those joint royal commissions I think that was in its mind, at least in part. The powers appropriate to a royal commission are probably appropriate for such a commission, but it needs to be said that while such a body might have special investigators it would still be operating with and through the normal police forces; it would not involve establishing a new arm or body of people for the normal enforcement of the law. Such a commission would be operating with and through the police forces of the Commonwealth and of the States.

Many people throughout the community believe that these issues need to be examined very seriously by governments at present. There is a widespread concern at the nature of crime, about which we read more and more as each year passes. Governments need to examine whether the traditional methods of law enforcement are adequate for the protection of the community. If there is corruption in high places, in a police force or anywhere else, and if it is not checked and rooted out, it tends to spread and become pervasive throughout society. That is something which I am sure this Parliament would be committed to preventing.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: POLICE RAID ON FERTILITY CONTROL CLINIC

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services as the Minister responsible for the Australian Federal Police. I refer to the raid on 19 February on the Fertility Control Clinic in Melbourne and subsequently on the home of Dr Wainer. I ask questions concerning the purpose of the raid and the material seized. Specifically, how was the Press informed of the raid on the clinic? How many police were involved in the raid and what was the purpose of having whatever number were involved? Are any charges to be laid? Why were the business partners of Dr Wainer not involved in police action in the same way as his home was raided? What was the reason for the delay in the raid, having regard to the fact that the Commonwealth Department of Health made inquiries in May and June of last year into certain matters concerning the charging of medical benefits items at the clinic?
—I remind the Minister of sub judice issues.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for giving me some warning earlier today that this question would be asked. I take note, Mr Speaker, of your caution about the sub judice rule. In relation to the question of the delay by the police in acting on the information, or the request, by the Department of Health -which I think was on 29 June-I am advised by the Police Commissioner that the amount of work and other matters referred to the police meant that their investigations were not completed until January of this year. The raid was then carried out. Secondly, as to the presence of the media at the clinic, I am further advised by the Police Commissioner that the media representatives did arrive 20 minutes after the raid commenced and that the police have no knowledge of how the media representatives may have arrived on the scene. I am advised that it was Dr Wainer who invited the media representatives to go inside after they had arrived on the scene.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member also asked for the number of policemen involved in the raid. I am advised by the Commissioner that 40 people were involved in the raid, and the Commissioner tells me that that was an operational decision; that that was the number of policemen needed, first of all, to execute 10 search warrants and interview eight people simultaneously. Of course, there were other related matters in the investigation.

The honourable member asked why Dr Wainer's home was treated differently from those of his partners. Again, I am advised that nothing set Dr Wainer's home apart from the homes of his partners. I am advised that a warrant was executed at the home of Dr Bayliss and one was in existence for premises at 52 Albany Road, Toorak, shown in records of the Corporate Affairs Commission as the home of Dr Rutman. These premises were, however, found to be in the course of construction and unoccupied. The home of Dr Wainer at 2 Reynolds Road, Research, was searched on 25 February after the doctor withdrew a restraining order obtained by him on 19 February.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware that the Queensland Premier, Mr Bjelke- Petersen, personally invited the USS Truxtun to visit Brisbane and that the nuclear warship will be arriving on Thursday, 29 April? Is he also aware that, when it appeared that Australian Atomic Energy Commission scientists might not be able to carry out radiation checks on the ship, the Queensland Premier was reported as saying that the Truxtun would berth in Brisbane whether or not radiation safety checks were made? Has the Prime Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that a radiation leak was detected from a sister ship of the USS Truxtun, the USS Longreach, while it was in port in Okinawa, Japan, in March 1980? Has his attention been drawn also to the recent statement by the Queensland Premier that primary responsibility for the overseeing of the nuclear industry should reside with the States? Finally, in view of the Queensland Premier's attitude to safety procedures surrounding the nuclear establishment, the USS Truxtun, what is his Government's policy with regard to Federal and State responsibility in the development of the nuclear industry and establishment of nuclear safeguards in Australia?

—The Commonwealth Government has established the procedures under which nuclear powered ships can visit Australian ports. Those procedures are clearly understood by port authorities. Provided those safety procedures are complied with, the policy of this Government is to encourage the visits of ships of allied navies and of the United States of America, and we will continue to do so. It has been my practice, when we are advised of an impending visit or a suggested visit by the United States, to write to the Premiers concerned to see whether they are agreeable to the visit. At this point I am not aware of any Premier having refused such a visit. I hope that those circumstances will not arise. The visits of nuclear powered warships to Cockburn Sound have been frequent and often in recent times. I believe that one of the nuclear powered aircraft carriers visited Hobart at an earlier point, but I stand subject to correction on that.
—The Enterprise.

—It was the Enterprise. Other visits have taken place. Visits to Brisbane by the USS Truxtun and maybe of other ships would be in conformity with existing policy and in support of the United States alliance. I hope the honourable member would support those visits and that practice, because, if we are to be allies of the United States, we need to make it quite plain that we establish the circumstance in which the alliance can be realistic. It can hardly be realistic if, even in spite of complying with all normal and appropriate safety requirements for nuclear powered ships, we say: 'Your ships cannot visit our ports'. I hope that that was not the position that the honourable member was adopting.
—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I think the Prime Minister misunderstood the question. I asked what was his Government's policy on nuclear safeguards, not whether the ship should come.
—There is no point of order. The question was almost out of order because it asked for the announcement of policy. The honourable member for Lilley was fortunate that I permitted the question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TELECOM AUSTRALIA: CLOSURE OF MANUAL ASSISTANCE CENTRES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Communications aware of plans by Telecom Australia to close a large number of manual assistance centres throughout Australia? I particularly refer to the centres at Swan Hill and Horsham in my electorate that are scheduled to close in 1983. This would leave the region of northern and western Victoria without any personalised directory, emergency or manual assistance services. As earlier rationalisation and regionalisation has not proved to be satisfactory, will the Minister ensure that Telecom reviews its plans in the interests of service to the community and retaining country employment opportunities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all of us recognise the tremendous contribution that telephonists have made towards the efficiency of the telephone network throughout Australia over the years. However, there have been changes, and these are reflected in the upgrading of manual exchanges to automatic and the progressive upgrading of switching arrangements themselves to enable more efficient and more comprehensive services. For example, the introduction of international subscriber dialling has come with the upgrading of these service centres. At the same time there is a problem in providing an adequate manual assistance form, given the automation of the system, and Telecom, in recognising the needs of its customers, is developing a program which will see some changes over the next few years.

ANSWER.PARA: I recognise the particular concern of the honourable gentleman which is reflected in quite a number of other areas. There is a worry about the extent to which these changes will disadvantage local employment and also affect the services available to local communities. Telecom hopes in the process of its analysis of its draft plans to take these factors into account. I have asked it to submit its recommendations to me before confirmation so that a final determination can be made taking into account the local employment opportunities and also the range of services that customers of Telecom rightly require.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Now that the Queen of Canada has granted her country full constitutional independence, will the Government request the Queen of Australia to do the same for our nation and, in particular, to remove the residual constitutional links between the Australian States and Britain which compromise Australian independence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has been trying to get agreement between the States on this matter for quite some time. As the honourable member would know, to the extent that those residual links have any meaning, they are likely to affect the States more than they would affect the Commonwealth, or its powers and laws. The attitudes of the States have in fact been different. The matter will be discussed, and I hope discussed in depth and brought to finality, at the forthcoming Premiers Conference. If we cannot get agreement between all the States, maybe we can achieve a solution that will, so long as there is agreement between the Commonwealth and a State, be progressed in relation to the particular State.

ANSWER.PARA: I think most members in the House would understand that the situations in Canada and Australia were markedly different. The Canadian Constitution was drawn before ours and no doubt our founding fathers learnt from the deficiencies which were already evident in the Canadian Constitution and which have been rectified only as a result of Prime Minister Trudeau's action. There was nothing built into the Canadian Constitution about means of revising, changing, altering or amending the Constitution. That was a great and grievous fault. However difficult it may be, there are processes for amendment of our Constitution which have been successful on a number of occasions, and that is one quite remarkable difference.

I was advised recently that until a very few years ago it was the practice of Her Majesty to sign the appointments of all ambassadors from Canada to other countries. I would have thought that that would be an odd circumstance, one that would hardly meet with the approval of any of the Australian governments of recent times.

There have been many differences between the campaign in Canada to break the residual links, as has been done in an amicable and appropriate way, and the circumstances which prevail in Australia. I think there were restraints in relation to Canada. I do not believe that Australian citizens are conscious of any restraints in this country as a result of any residual links that may exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the Government's decision to recall Australia's Ambassador to Argentina for consultations following the Argentine invasion of the Falkland Islands. Is the Ambassador expected to return to Buenos Aires in the near future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time of the Argentine invasion of the Falkland Islands this Government, because of the seriousness with which it viewed the situation, recalled our Ambassador, Mr Dan, for urgent consultations. The Canadian Government also recalled its Ambassador. Mr Dan left Argentina on 6 April and reported to me immediately he arrived here on 9 April. After a period of further consultations in the Department it was decided that Mr Dan should go to New York for consultations with the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations and others on United Nations aspects of the Falklands situation.

ANSWER.PARA: It has now been decided, following those consultations, that Mr Dan should return to his post in Buenos Aires because a crucial and sensitive period in the Falklands crisis now lies ahead. It is a period in which every effort must be made to convince Argentina that its interests and those of the international community are best served through the process of negotiation rather than armed conflict. Upon his return to Argentina, Mr Dan will convey a personal message from me to the Argentine Foreign Minister. Although the contents of that message must remain confidential at this stage, it will make absolutely clear the seriousness with which this Government views the Argentine invasion of the Falklands and emphasise our belief that Argentina should comply with resolution 502 of the United Nations Security Council calling on it to withdraw its troops as the basis for a diplomatic solution.

Mr Dan, as is normal for an ambassador, will be reporting on developments in the Falklands and in Argentina. He will take responsibility again for Australian interests, including the welfare of Australian citizens. He is to return to Buenos Aires today. The Canadian Ambassador returned on 20 April.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister a question. Is he correctly quoted in the current issue of the Bulletin which states that he claims his Government is ' taking less of each dollar produced in Australia, 2 to 2.5 less', whatever that may mean? Do the Budget Estimates for this year show that in fact his Government is collecting 25.5c in tax revenue for each dollar produced, compared with 25.2c per dollar in 1975-76? Is it not a fact that, far from reducing Federal tax, his Government has increased it by between 2c and 2.5c for each dollar produced? Is it not also a fact that his Government has become the highest taxing government in our history? Is this not a betrayal of promises solemnly made by the Prime Minister, at three elections over the past seven years, that taxes would be reduced?

—When the Leader of the Opposition asks questions of this kind he always conveniently forgets that the deficits of Labor governments were leading to a deficit approaching 5 per cent of gross domestic product. If we want to find out the demands of government on the resources of the country, we have to take not only the actual taxation that is collected in any one year but also have to add to that the deficit which has to be funded in one way or another. While the Labor deficits were growing dramatically and approaching 5 per cent-I think they were 4.9 per cent at the maximum-under this Government the deficits have been reduced to around 1 per cent or less. At the end of the three years of the Labor Government that Government was taking about 6.5c more out of every dollar produced. After the period that this Government has been in office we are taking 2c to 2.5c less out of each dollar produced. That takes into account not only taxation revenue but also deficit financing.
—Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to the United Kingdom Employment Bill 1982? Are any aspects of this legislation of relevance to Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, the United Kingdom Employment Bill 1982 does have relevance to the legislation I presented to this House, which was passed by this House and is now before the Senate. The United Kingdom Employment Bill seeks to attack an area of fundamental concern to that country. This Government's Bill attacks the same area of concern; that is, the rights of the individual and the closed shop system of excluding people from their normal occupations unless they join a particular union. There is that similarity between what we are seeking to achieve in Australia and what the Thatcher Government is seeking to achieve in the United Kingdom. One other important area that the United Kingdom legislation opens up is to expose trade union funds to suits for damages. Of course, the House will be aware that in our legislation to support voluntary unionism we, likewise, will expose trade union funds to suits for damages or compensation at the hands of an individual who has been discriminated against or victimised because that individual has chosen to exercise his personal right not to belong to a union.

ANSWER.PARA: The United Kingdom legislation is going through the House of Commons. I was interested-if I might inform my colleague-to read some of the United Kingdom Press reports which, before the debate in the House of Commons, noted that there was no provision in the legislation with respect to what the British call 'lay- offs'. The term used in Australia, of course, is 'stand-downs'. It was seen in the United Kingdom that something needed to be done within its industrial relations legislation to allow employers to protect themselves against industrial action which meant that they could not continue usefully to employ their employees.

I was interested to note also, with respect to the United Kingdom legislation, that the Thatcher Government is concerned to outlaw what are, in effect, secondary boycotts brought by one union against a company which is not unionised . Of course, it is some years since we amended the Trade Practices Act to outlaw secondary boycotts in Australia. I know that it has been suggested in some quarters that our legislation is not widely supported in Australia. I believe that that assertion is quite wrong. In the three areas in which we have moved- voluntary unionism, standing down of employees and industry unions-there has been widespread support from the man or the woman in the street, from unions and from companies. The latest evidence of this widespread support comes from the National Farmers Federation which, at the conference being held at the moment, unanimously resolved to support the Government's legislation. A Press statement to that effect has been released today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Would you, Mr Speaker, under Standing Order 321, require the Minister to table the document from which he has been reading?
—Was the Minister reading from a document?
—Mr Speaker, I would be quite happy to incorporate the document from which I was reading, the Press release of the National Farmers Federation. I ask for leave to incorporate the document.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
April 28, 1982
Strong Farmer Support for Industrial Legislation
The annual conference of the National Farmers' Federation in Canberra today gave strong support to Federal industrial legislation presently before the Senate.
President of the NFF, Mr Michael Davidson, said the conference was unanimous in its support for:
voluntary unionism,
standing down of employees, and
industry unions.
Mr Davidson said farmers supported the concept of freedom of choice of individuals and completely opposed the principle of employees being forced to join an organisation against their will.
'Farmers also support the right of employers to stand down employees who cannot be usefully employed because of industrial action,' he said.
Mr Davidson endorsed the concept of industry unions and said the proposed legislation should facilitate the formation of such unions where this was seen to be desirable by union members.
'The process of establishing industry unions will take a number of years,' Mr Davidson said.
Further Information: Mr Jim Macnamara, Director Public Relations, National Farmers' Federation, Phone (062) 73 3855 or a.h. (062) 31 3569

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Prime Minister. It follows a question that I asked him a few seconds ago. I am grateful to him for his little homily on the need--
—The honourable gentleman will ask his question.

—To relate the tax burden to the Budget deficit to establish an accurate measure of the Government's demand for resources in the economy. Following that, I therefore ask the Prime Minister whether it is a fact that, as a proportion of gross domestic product, the level of tax plus the deficit under Labor was 25.6 per cent, but that under his Government it is well over 26 per cent. Is it also a fact that if one takes account of the size of the total public sector under the two Governments, the average public sector share of gross domestic product under Labor was just over 35 per cent, compared with nearly 39 per cent under his Government? Is it a fact that the Budget Papers make it clear that the public sector indeed will be nearly 40 per cent of GDP this year? Finally, will the Prime Minister therefore cease persisting with his version of Barnum bunkum, of trying to fool all of the people all of the time, and deal reliably and accurately with the statistics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the Leader of the Opposition has used average figures over three years of Labor government and over a period of this Government, and those averages totally distort the story that he seeks to give. In fact, the very averages themselves indicate that the reverse is the truth, because the Labor Government of 1972 inherited an economy that was strong and well-based but had relatively low levels of taxation and responsible levels of government expenditure. One has only to look at the 10 per cent increase in real terms in each of the following three years, which occurred under Labor, the massive increase in Commonwealth employment and the massive increases in expenditure-in one Budget alone, expenditure increased by 46 per cent in one year, and in other years it increased by figures between 20 per cent and 25 per cent-to realise that in these circumstances the Labor Government was on a rising plane of expenditure and a rising plane of demand on the nation's resources. It is not much consolation to the last of that failed lot of Treasurers to be able to say that the average was not all that bad, because they started with some good figures that they had inherited from an earlier administration. We inherited at the outset the kinds of figures that were left in the Labor Budget and we have been working to diminish the deficit, to diminish the demand for resources and to free resources so that they can be used by individuals in Australia rather than be absorbed and taken charge of totally by governments. So we are on a falling plane of demand for resources; the Labor Party was on a rising plane. The averages about which the Leader of the Opposition spoke totally distort the attitudes of the Labor Government and what he was trying to depict about the attitudes of this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: We have only to take the circumstances in which the Leader of the Opposition has himself said that he is a high tax man-he has made that very plain-and in which his shadow Treasurer has said that Labor will face a mammoth task of persuading the electorate that it will have to fund a larger public sector under Labor than would be the case under this Government, to see that it is perfectly plain that, whatever the Labor Party may say, its real wishes are for a larger public sector, under Labor control, and that has to mean a larger deficit or higher taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Is it a fact that one of the main problems facing disabled people is in finding employment and being trained so that they can obtain employment? Was any progress made in improving the employability of disabled people during the International Year of Disabled Persons? If so, will that work continue now that the IYDP is over?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown Mr N.A.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: EMPLOYMENT AND YOUTH AFFAIRS; CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that one of the major problems facing disabled people is in their obtaining work experience and training to enable them to obtain work , and to keep it, and to take a full part in normal community life. It is also true that during 1981, which was the International Year of Disabled Persons, the Commonwealth Government, with the States and through the Commonwealth Employment Service and a range of voluntary bodies, made considerable progress in improving the employability of very many disabled people. This was done through subsidies to employers to encourage them to take on disabled people and give them work experience and job opportunities. I think jobs were found last year for some 14, 000 disabled people, which was an increase of certainly over 50 per cent on 1980 . I can assure the honourable member that the efforts which were made during 1981 will certainly be continued this year and in the future. The Commonwealth Employment Service will continue to do everything possible to provide work experience and training for disabled people so that more of them can find employment, keep it and lead a useful, active and enjoyable life.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the figures I have just referred to, I have reminded myself-and no doubt the honourable member will not be at all surprised to hear this-that his State of Queensland led in the creation of employment opportunities for disabled people. Last year in Queensland more than 5,000 people were placed in employment under our programs through the CES, which was some 2,000 more than the figure recorded by Queensland's nearest rival, New South Wales. But the national picture was indeed very good. Great improvements were made in the employment prospects for disabled people. We certainly will be taking every step to ensure that those efforts are continued.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: EMPLOYMENT AND YOUTH AFFAIRS; CONSUMER AFFAIRS

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REVIEW OF CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION: TAXATION RECORDS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the honourable gentleman's recent interest in the detection of corruption and illegality at all levels of society, including government departments and police forces. Accordingly, I ask: Why is it that the Government has decided not to act on the recommendations of Mr Justice Williams for access to taxation records to be made available to the police per medium of judicial warrants? Further, what is the reason for the Prime Minister's decision to refuse the person responsible for the review of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Mahony, power to look at Customs entry into all ports of Australia, particularly where heroin is concerned, and also the decision to refuse Mr Mahony the power to summon witnesses, require the production of documents and have access to taxation records?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the last part of the honourable gentleman's question I point out that both the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and the Joint Commonwealth-New South Wales Task Force on Drug Trafficking are specifically related to drugs. Anything related to those matters can be adequately covered by the royal commissions. If they cannot, as we have indicated on other occasions, we are fully prepared to see that the terms of reference are widened, if that can be demonstrated to be necessary. We have done that in the past.

ANSWER.PARA: The inquiry into Customs matters is an administrative one because clearly there have been some administrative shortfalls. This has been recognised by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Public Service Board over the last couple of years. New arrangements have been under examination and are shortly to be put in force. But the inquiry will enable those matters to be taken into account to see whether, in the judgment of a very experienced person, the new arrangements will be adequate and will contribute sufficiently to sort out other problems that may be within the Department. Having in mind the nature of the inquiry-it is forward looking and will make sure that the Department is functioning properly and that laws and rules are being equally and appropriately applied to all Australian citizens-and the terms in which it has been mounted, we believe it will best serve the needs as the Government sees them.

Mr Justice Williams's recommendations have been acted upon in relation to the royal commissions and not in relation to the police at this point. I think the honourable member would recognise that even to make the records available to the royal commissioners under the same conditions of secrecy as applied to the Commissioner of Taxation would be a very substantial step indeed. It is a break with tradition and practice. The short answer to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition's question is that we believed that there was a necessity to take this step but we wanted to assess the results from that before considering whether further action ought to be taken. But a very substantial step has been taken in relation to the royal commissions and access to records. I hope that the Deputy Leader recognises that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Trade and Resources seen reports that companies exporting coal through Newcastle have had quotas placed on the export of their products? Is the reason for the quotas the lack of loading facilities at Newcastle? Has any assessment been made of the loss of export earnings, the cost to current and future contracts and to the central reduction in jobs and the tax contribution that could be made by these companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is only one way to describe the coal handling operations at Newcastle, and that is to say that there has been a tragic debacle within a series of industrial disputes and an inability of the New South Wales Government to resolve the arrangements for the building of further coal handling facilities. This has caused an undue delay to the point now where we have a rather embarrassing sight of anything up to 50 ships waiting off-shore incurring enormous demurrage costs. That demurrage has been calculated at something like $ 5 a tonne to the industry. When one considers that over the total tonnage going out of Newcastle one sees that an enormous amount of money is being lost to the industry in that region and to Australia. My understanding of the situation is that to try to meet the chaotic situation at the moment the New South Wales Government, the Joint Coal Board and the colliery owners have come together on a quota plan which is to operate from 1 May.

ANSWER.PARA: No spot sales or new contracts can be entered into for that year once the quota scheme is in operation. TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the third annual report of the Australia-China Council for the year ended 30 June 1981. I seek leave to make a short statement on the activities of the Council.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —A sound and dynamic relationship with China is accepted by both sides of the House as a vital element in Australia's foreign policy. It was with this in mind that in 1978 this Government moved to form the Australia-China Council. The Council has a distinguished membership which is committed to fostering contacts between Australian and Chinese media groups and specialists in the fields of science, the arts, social sciences, sport and education. It is now well established, and is performing creditably its intended role of furthering our ties with the People's Republic of China. While the Council has an important role to play, the Government during the year moved in other ways to consolidate Australia's relations with China. I bring some of these to the attention of honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: Visits in both directions at ministerial and vice-ministerial level have proved most valuable. My own visit to Beijing in January last year enabled me to meet Chinese leaders and to advance several bilateral issues. Official visits were also made by my colleagues, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and the former Minister for Health the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), who, during his visit, signed a technical co-operation agreement between Australia and China. A bilateral cultural exchanges agreement was signed during a visit to Australia by China's Minister for Culture in 1981. In September last year a protocol to the 1973 trade agreement was signed during a visit to Australia by the Chinese Vice-Minister for Foreign Trade.

I turn now to some activities of the Council during the year in question. With the active help of the Council, China's new English language newspaper the China Daily commenced publication in June 1981. Through the United Nations association , the Council sponsored a Joint Australia-China Press seminar in Beijing. The seminar looked at case studies of Press reporting in both countries about the other.

A most imaginative cultural venture was undertaken by the Australian company Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd during the year, when a priceless exhibition of classical Chinese paintings was brought to Australia. The outstanding success of this event was helped by the Council's efforts in bringing to this country several prominent Chinese artists to complement the exhibition. These artists were able to explain something of the techniques and meaning of Chinese art to Australians. Grants were made by the Council for exchanges of professional visits, study and collaborative research in various areas of science, medicine and engineering. One particular research program already under way in the field of geology is expected to yield valuable information on water and soil resources for both countries over the next few years. A group of Aboriginal health workers went to China during the year to study China's well developed system of rural health care. This project went ahead on the recommendation of the National Aboriginal Advisory Council.

In Australia, the Australia-China Council has initiated several programs which promote both the teaching of the Chinese language in Australian schools and the training of a corps of Australian interpreters with Chinese language skills. This body of trained interpreters will be invaluable in assisting both government and industry in further developing contacts with China.

Finally, the Council in its day to day activities serves as a centre for advice and an organisation to which the general public can direct inquiries about China . Its regular newsletter is an important aspect of this advising and disseminating work. The Council's activities have the wholehearted support not only of this Government but also of the Chinese Government. It gives me great pleasure to table the Australia-China Council's report for 1980-81.

INTERJECT.PARA: The neglect by the Federal Government of the real needs of the Tasmanian economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker--
—You don't even know where Tasmania is.

—One of the needs for this debate has just been illustrated by the comments of the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman) who is sitting at the table. Much noise comes from the representatives of Tasmania in this House but there is very little creative thinking about the particular problems that face that State. The first thing that must be said about the economy of Tasmania is that in essence the very real problems Tasmania faces are the responsibility of the Government which sits in this place. One would say that of all the States whether they be Liberal or Labor. The fact that they face economic problems, that most of them today face stagnant economies and that relatively speaking all of them have high levels of unemployment is not primarily the responsibility of their State governments but the result of economic policies pursued from this place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is about time in debates in this place that we avoided the simple and easy point-scoring tactics. If members want to have a go at some State government they blame it for unemployment, they blame it for inflation and they blame it for a stagnant economy. If we are to have a real and worthwhile debate, particularly about the regional economic problems that this country faces, we must tackle the problem other than by point-scoring tactics in which people simply pour scorn on particular State governments for aspects of their economic management and blame them for the problems which all Australian States suffer and which derive very much from the policies pursued in this place.

When we have economic arguments about the state of the nation, let us make it quite clear that the buck stops here. I am quite prepared to apply that principle to Labor and Liberal States. For instance, Tasmania and South Australia have competed over the last two years in terms of high unemployment rates. It is not a matter in respect of which competition is particularly admirable, but for the last 12 months those two States have competed for the position of having the highest rates of unemployment in this country. Let me say that the unemployment rates in those two States have very little to do either with the Lowe-Holgate State Government or the Tonkin Government. They have most to do with the Government that sits here.

Let me just make one aside about the Premier of South Australia. Dr Tonkin's only error was to convince the South Australian people in the 1979 election that he could solve all these economic problems. He therefore generated expectations about State economic power which, of course, he was not able to meet. But the economic problems his Government now faces, just as the economic problems the Tasmanian Government faces, are primarily the responsibility of the Government here. The fact is that both the Tasmanian and South Australian economies at the present stage of Australia's economic development-this is not to say that this will last for all time; it certainly was not true at times in the past-are vulnerable and are most likely to suffer severely in periods of recession. If a recession is generated by economic policies pursued here from Canberra those vulnerable States such as South Australia and Tasmania and, perhaps to a lesser extent, Victoria, will be most severely affected.

One of the problems that this country will have to face in the 1980s is that it is creating potentially two Australias. One Australia will comprise the economically resource rich States possessing those resources which are valued at this stage of development. I refer to New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia as the resource rich States, the economically advantaged States. The second Australia will comprise Tasmania, South Australia and Victoria. Those States at this stage are have-not States. As I shall point out later, the policies pursued for the last seven years from the Government benches in this Parliament have tended to lay the foundations for a widening gap between the resource rich States and the other States whereas it should be the task of any Federal government to unite the nation, to pursue economic policies and direct them at States such as Tasmania because--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you raising this now?

—I will respond to the honourable member for Braddon. Given that this House has five members supposedly representing Tasmania, issues on Tasmania are practically never raised by this representation which will last for little more than another 18 months. As I suggested before these very noisy interruptions from the Tasmanian representatives, who are rarely heard in this House-in fact they have grown particularly quiet of late-the task of a responsible federal government should be to try to break down this economic division which may mean economic distributive policies in favour of those States which are weaker in the valued resources of a particular time. At the moment the resources which are much valued in economic development internationally and in this country are the transportable energy resources such as coal and gas-with which Tasmania is not well supplied-and of course bauxite.

SPEECH.PARA: Tasmania in many ways is the most vulnerable of the State economies, the one most dependent on intelligent federal economic policies. I quote an analysis by a Tasmanian economist, Mr Wilde, as to some forms of vulnerability in the Tasmanian economy:

Hampered by its very weak and inflexible financial base and physical isolation, and overwhelmed by outside economic forces, a Tasmanian government can do little to support or attract industry especially in competition with the wealthier States and is hard pressed to formulate feasible long term plans in isolation.

All of those points very much need stressing. They are: Tasmania's weak financial base, its physical isolation, the fact that it can so easily be overwhelmed by outside economic forces, the difficulties a Tasmanian government has in attracting industry, particularly in competition with the wealthier States, and the difficulties of a Tasmanian government formulating a feasible long term plan in isolation. It cannot do this without proper planning and backing from a Federal government with the economic resources. The same point has been made in one of the best reports on the Tasmanian economy that I have read. I would suggest that all honourable members from Tasmania read it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one was that?
—You are just an apologist for Holgate.

—I will wait until this noisy individual is finished. This document is a report of an inquiry into the structure of industry and the employment situation in Tasmania. I quote from Sir Bede Callaghan's report entitled 'Inquiry into the Structure of Industry and the Employment Situation in Tasmania', which echoes the points I have just made and supports the proposals made by Mr Wilde. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: As indicated to some extent above, the structure of the Tasmanian industry reflects the general position-declining rural and manufacturing activity and limited private tertiary sector development due to isolation, seasonality and/or transport disabilities with a cost/price squeeze apparent in almost every area.

He points out there the need for Commonwealth support in the development of this economy. What we are saying is that the Tasmanian economy needs the adoption of positive economic policies by a protective Federal government. It needs Federal public investment to offset the competitive disadvantages from which the Tasmanian economy suffers. Government policies directed at reducing the public sector-that has been the whole thrust of this Federal Government's policies-to satisfy a rampant business ideology that somehow alleges it is necessary to free capital for private investment simply damage States like Tasmania. In supposedly freeing those States and communities heavily dependent on public spending to generate economic activity, they simply force them to generate longer and longer unemployment queues.

Public investment and private investment in this country are complementary not antithetic. I draw the attention of the Minister for the Capital Territory to his bailiwick: Canberra is one of the great examples of this. For a long time- before some of the marauding activities of the present Government-public and private investment worked to develop this city. Tasmanian experience exemplifies that superbly. The whole base of the successful Tasmanian economic experience of the 1950s and the 1960s was the product of major public investment by the Ogilvie and Cosgrove governments, which laid the foundation of Tasmanian growth and expansion. These are the roles that State government can play. I remind the questioning honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom), who is attempting to interject, that that activity by the Tasmanian State governments in the 1930s and the 1940s was very much supported by co-operative Liberal and Labor Federal governments.

I turn now to the sources of the vulnerability in the Tasmanian economy. First of all, the Tasmanian population is much more decentralised than that of other States. Therefore, the service demands on government will be greater. Every cut made in public services-the delivering of services to people-affects the States, but it affects particularly States like Tasmania which, because of the decentralisation of their population, need wide support services. Secondly, the work force in Tasmania represents a smaller percentage of the population than is the case in other States. That means that the number of people dependent on welfare provisions and old age support is much greater in Tasmania. Of course, there is much posturing by some Tasmanian members about the provisions made for the old in this society. This applies particularly to Tasmania, where there is a greater percentage of elderly people than there is in any other State. Indeed, if one looks at the income that people can earn over the basic levels, if one looks at the fringe benefit levels, one will find that in real terms in the past seven years there has been a cut in the provision made for the elderly. That cut affects Tasmania in particular because of the nature of its population.

Finally, of course, Tasmania faces the problem of geographical isolation. Let it be said that, in relation to all of those four points, it is necessary that public investment, public activity, play a major role. Tasmania has a particularly vulnerable economy. I could go on at great length to illustrate what is occurring in a whole range of fields-for example, housing. I want to finish briefly on a creative note and to say that if we are to solve the sorts of problems that Tasmania and a number of other States face we must develop regional economic policies whereby, for instance, the tax sharing entitle- ments must be augmented by a Commonwealth program aimed to give a greater stimulus to private sector economic developments in States with weaker economic bases. There must be a planned and developed policy tied in with the general way of reimbursing the States so that we make up for the disadvantages of those States which at present-maybe not in the 1990s or in the next century- have weak economic bases.

It is imperative in this planning that we take into account the overall macroeconomic effect of the way in which the State spends its own grants. Secondly, it is equally important to ensure that a program exists to equalise regional opportunities. But without those sorts of programs, without a Federal government being prepared actively to develop and support regional economic programs, not only Tasmania but also South Australia and Victoria will be disadvantaged in the coming decades.
