Their hard work, their efforts and their dedication have resulted in many successes and a great deal of assistance being provided by the Federal Government. Let me refer to some of the initiatives. One was the freight equalisation scheme which was brought down in 1976.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many of them are Catholics?
—What would you know about Tasmania? You have never been there.

—Order! The honourable member for Port Adelaide will remain silent. I suggest to honourable gentleman that if they are determined to have a brief romp they do so with a degree of dignity and observe the forms of the House.

—In 1976 we brought in the freight equalisation scheme. This has been vital to the economy of our State. This financial year the Federal Government is providing $33m to help industries right around the State. This assistance has saved and secured many thousands of jobs. I make the point that we have no intention of decreasing assistance under the freight equalisation scheme or in any way downgrading that important scheme. It is worth while noting that this scheme now applies to air transport during strikes. When businesses cannot get their goods to market because of maritime strikes they can under that scheme get help from the Government for the cost of freighting their goods by air to markets.

SPEECH.PARA: Another initiative is the landbridge formula which provides a subsidy for air fares between mainland Tasmania and mainland Australia. This has cushioned the impact of air fares on people going to and from our State. It is a 10 per cent subsidy. This important initiative will cost $4m in the present financal year. It is worth noting that this scheme also applies to Fokker Friendship services to the north-west provided by both Ansett Airlines of Australia and East West Airlines.

Another initiative has been the Callaghan report. The Minister for Administrative Services, who has just entered the chamber, is very much responsible for the important work under the Callaghan plan. This plan is now under active review. There has been a problem because of lack of co-operation by the Tasmanian Government in some areas-in some areas it has been co-operative- and a lack of imagination and a vision of what can be achieved in Tasmania.

The honourable member for Bonython, who is from South Australia, talks about neglect, but he did not mention the second Hobart bridge. He did not mention the Australian Maritime College. He did not mention the Antarctic base in Hobart. He did not mention the assistance for the Mount Lyell Mining and Railway Co. Ltd at a time when the people of Queenstown were very concerned because copper prices had gone down and that town and the jobs of the people employed by Mount Lyell were threatened. The Government provided ready assistance to secure the future of that important town on the west coast of Tasmania. Early last year when the town of Zeehan was threatened by serious bushfires the Prime Minister immediately expressed his personal concern and provided assistance for the people of Zeehan. That assistance was gratefully received by them. Help has also been given to the apple industry. The honourable member for Franklin has given great support to the apple industry and is always putting forward its interests in this House.

When I look at all of those initiatives and all that has been done, I ask: Where is the neglect? In almost every department and every area of expenditure Tasmanians are receiving more per capita than any of the other States. The average amount being paid by the Commonwealth per capita to Tasmanians is between $1,200 and $1,300. For the larger States it is $400 to $600. I do not want to over-emphasise those facts, but Tasmania receives about double the amount of the larger, more populous States. We are reasonably happy with that, but we are still fighting to see whether we can get more for our State. Those figures must be compared with the abysmal performance of the Harry Holgate Labor Government in Tasmania; the worst government, I suggest to the House, ever to hold office anywhere in Australia, if not the world. It set up a potato industry authority at great cost and then abandoned it. An amount of $16m was lost on the Electrona Canbide Industries Pty Ltd deal and Mr Holgate sold it for one dollar. There was a $13.5m deficit on hospital funding and again the Holgate Government tried to blame the Federal Government but clearly on the facts it was the responsibility of the State Government. Half a million dollars was lost on the installation of boilers at St Johns Park. An amount of $1m was lost on the infamous Bowen pyramids. That Government retained the services of the other Harry, Harry Butler, as a conservation consultant at $625 a day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where has he gone?

—We do not know where he has gone. That was obviously a waste of money and effort to confuse the people of Tasmania. The total shambles over the south- west power scheme has gone on and on for years and years and is a complete mess. This has cost the people of Tasmania something like $80m. There have been continual squabbles between Ministers and the Tasmanian Hydro-Electric Commission. A fortune was spend on accommodating public servants in London. We are told that something like $160,000 was spent on a house for a trade official in London.
—How much?

—One hundred and sixty thousand dollars. At one stage $12,000 was paid for six months rent for that person's accommodation. What a waste of public money! An amount of $3m was wasted on the Launceston General Hospital laundry while other laundries in the area could have done the job. There are broken promises galore, including that of the north-west regional water scheme. Promises were made and have been broken by Mr Holgate and his crew. He denied power to the people of King Island and Flinders Island. Evidence has come to light of a 30-year supply of land for housing. The Holgate Government screams for more money for housing. I suppose that is fair enough, but at the same time it has 30 years supply of land sitting all around that State. What is it doing with it. The people in that Government could not manage a small country shop.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the Fraser Government has been very fair and very generous to the people of Tasmania. The members in this House who have been fighting for the constituents in the small State have made sure of that. The shadow Minister for Tasmanian affairs should be replaced. He has been hiding somewhere. He has never been prepared to come out into the open and speak about Tasmania. Any time he wants to take us on and talk about Tasmania, we will say: 'Good on him'. The more opportunities that we have in this House to talk about Tasmania, the better . We will support him all the way. We hope that he brings forward more matters of public importance and motions concerning Tasmania so that we can debate these issues with him. But he should not be involved with this cunning and conniving Mr Harry Holgate and his Government of lifeless men.

We, on this side of the House-I am sure the honourable member for Franklin will support me-say that this claim made in the matter of public importance is totally false. We totally reject it on behalf of the Tasmanians that we represent. We have been fairly treated by this Federal Government. I suppose we could always ask for a bit more: that is true. But if all the hard facts and figures are looked at objectively and if we do not talk philosophy it will be seen that Tasmanians are, I would say, doing reasonably well at the moment out of the Commonwealth coffers. But that is not to say that the Tasmanian members of this Parliament are totally satisfied. We will continue to fight. The job is not done yet. We will continue to fight as hard as we can for the people we represent in Tasmania.

The people made a judgment in 1975. Before that there were five parliamentary members of the Australian Labor Party from Tasmania. Now there are five parliamentary Liberal Party members from Tasmania. All the Tasmanian seats are held by Liberals. We intend to keep it that way. The results are on the board. We have worked as hard as we can. The two Ministers, the honourable member for Bass and the honourable member for Denison, and the three back bench members from Tasmania have worked as hard as they can.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Denison worked hard all right, he took your job.
—All right, you say he took my job. He is doing a damn good job. I am happy here, where I am, and he is happy where he is, but we will continue to work as hard as we can for the people we represent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We on this side of the House brought forward this matter of public importance because we believe that the Federal Government is neglecting the real needs of the Tasmanian economy. Nothing that the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) said has convinced me otherwise. It is a pity that he took it upon himself to abuse my colleague, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), rather than to discuss the issues. I take him up on one thing: If the Tasmanian members of this House are so deeply interested in everything that affects Tasmania, why is there not a single question on the Notice Paper by any of the Tasmanian members? Tasmania is represented federally in this House by five Government members. Clearly, when the real needs of Tasmania's economy are examined we come to the inescapable conclusion that the five sitting members do not fight hard enough. Perhaps they find it hard to fight the Liberal Party's economic philosophy even though their State suffers. Tasmania is experiencing all those economic ills that are affecting every State in Australia, but they are exacerbated because it is such a small State.

SPEECH.PARA: The indications are that the level of unemployment-the approximate Australian average is 6.9 per cent-has risen to a dramatic 9.2 per cent in Tasmania. I have not heard any of the Tasmanian members mention that when we have been debating unemployment. Some 14,700 people are out of work in Tasmania, which has, without doubt, the worst record in Australia. Yet in this House we do not hear any condemnation from the Tasmanian members of those devastating figures. The social consequences of such a level of unemployment are horrific. Without doubt it is the policy of 'fight inflation first' pursued by this Government which is the main cause of increasingly high unemployment. While the total level of unemployment in mainland Aus- tralia has risen by 11.5 per cent in the year to March, in Tasmania the increase was 33.8 per cent. The young people in Tasmania are worse off with an unemployment level of 30.5 per cent. I consider these to be crisis figures and expect the Tasmanian members to urge the Government to reconsider its economic strategy.

The philosophical commitment of this Government appears to be directed towards ensuring that the most deprived members of the community carry the heaviest burden which, in this case, is the Tasmanians. It is useless for Federal Government members to try to hang the blame for the high levels of unemployment in Tasmania on the Tasmanian Government. In this House we constantly hear every ill blamed on three years of the Whitlam Federal Government, but I remind the House, even though it is now six years later, that the complete acceptance has been, even by this Government, that the Federal Government's policies are responsible for unemployment. National growth in the work force was 2 per cent. In Tasmania the labour force fell by 0.8 per cent. This Government's policies are decimating Tasmania.

The Federal Government's new tax sharing arrangements have profound implications for the people of Tasmania. Tasmania's tax sharing grant was increased by only 8.7 per cent in 1981-82. As the rate of inflation was 10.5 per cent the Commonwealth in fact reduced Tasmania's share in real terms, and its five members are quite happy about that. Unless the Commonwealth is prepared to maintain the value of the States grants in real terms, the State governments, and Tasmania as a prime example, will have to look for their income elsewhere. Must the Tasmanian people be forced to pay higher taxes within their State to compensate for the Commonwealth's inadequate funding? What do the Tasmanian members have to say about this? Does this not run counter to the Commonwealth's stated objective of reducing the overall burden of taxation in Australia?

I repeat what I have said before in this House: This is the highest taxing government in the history of Australia. Tasmania actually received $18m less last year than the amount it would have received under the old guidelines. Couple this with the enormous drop-off in funding for health and Tasmania's disadvantaged position is clearly shown. Under the new health plan-Medibank Mark V or VI, or whatever it is-Tasmania was told by the Liberal Government to raise $33.5m from new charges. The State Government responsible advised the Commonwealth that the estimate was unreal and that it would find it difficult to raise $26m. In fact, Tasmania raised only $20m because of the number of patients who, under this Government's guidelines, were deemed to be non-chargeable. The Tasmanian Government was then faced with a $13.5m deficit in its public hospitals on top of the $18m less that it received from the tax sharing grants.

In Tasmania the housing industry, an accepted economic indicator, is operating at its lowest level since the 1960s. This Government's policies on interest rates and taxation have adversely affected the building industry and, through it , the Tasmanian people. However, in spite of the Commonwealth's restricted financing for public and welfare housing throughout Australia, the Tasmanian Government must be congratulated in that it has been able to increase the annual addition to public housing stock. The public housing stock is a large proportion of total housing in Tasmania. In 1979-80 22 per cent of the total dwellings completed were in the public sector, compared with 6 per cent nationally. That is a great record for any government. The Tasmanian Government can also be congratulated in that it spent $25 per head on public housing in 1980-81 against the national average of $18 per head. Victorian members, who daily have constituents looking for cheaper housing, will envy what the Tasmanian Government has achieved. Now that we have a Labor Government in Victoria we will hope to see an increase in expenditure on public housing there also. I point out also that Tasmania's housing interest rates are on a par with those in New South Wales and are lower than those in most conservative States. Despite the severe restrictions placed upon its economy by this Government, the Tasmanian Government has done well by the people of Tasmania and will continue to do so. It is a great pity that the honourable members in this House who represent the State are not more assiduous in fighting the Liberal Government to get a better deal for Tasmanians.

I comment briefly on the fact that the Labor Party believes there should be an open and public environmental impact study on the entire issue of the south-west wilderness area of Tasmania. After all, the present Liberal Federal Government has nominated the area as one of the rare environmental treasures to be placed on the World Heritage List. In doing so the Commonwealth Government has assumed a responsibility for this area. The Liberal Party and the community generally are divided on the issue but we certainly are united in our call for a Federal environmental impact study on the entire issue. The Age editorial referred to this matter on Thursday, 25 February this year. This very good editorial stated:

Mr Fraser must be joking. His claim to the Federal Parliament on Tuesday that the proposed Gordon-below-Franklin Dam in south-west Tasmania was purely a State responsibility, was wrong in principle and wrong in law. The Prime Minister has gladly accepted the praise for placing south-west Tasmania, including the Lower Gordon and Franklin Rivers on the register of the National Estate. His Government has now also nominated the area as one of the rare environmental treasures to be placed on the World Heritage List. These actions clearly place a moral responsibility on the Commonwealth to do its best to ensure that the timeless beauty of the wild rivers is not wantonly destroyed. To try to wash ones hands of the issue in these circumstances is a humbug.
In conclusion, the editorial says:

To pretend that the Commonwealth can simply opt out and leave it to the States is not merely to repeat the mistakes of Lake Pedder, it is to invite Mr Bjelke- Petersen to do what he likes with the Great Barrier Reef and to allow any other parochial Premier to destroy part of the National Estate for a quick buck. That is not what the Australians want to expect from their Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you like an extension of time? You are winning us a lot of votes.
—That will not be necessary, Mr Minister. I quote further from this excellent editorial in the Age. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: One should note that, on financial grounds, Mr Fraser virtually ruled out the prospect of infrastructure borrowing for the proposed dam in the near future.
Earlier, it stated:

It also ignores the obligations imposed on the Commonwealth by law. The Australian Heritage Commission Act forbids a Federal Minister taking action which would adversely affect any part of the National Estate unless there is no feasible and prudent alternative. In theory, as Mr Fraser says, Tasmania could pay for the $1116 million dam from its general loan allocation, or indeed from its own State revenue, without the Commonwealth being involved. In practice, general loan allocations have been cut so much that Tasmania could raise the necessary finance only by infrastructure borrowing. And this would require the approval of a Federal Minister.

That is wrong in law. He has no responsibility; he will be obliged to obey the Heritage Commission Act. At the very least, this would require a proper federal inquiry into the proposed dam and the alternatives to it. That is what we on this side of the House are calling for. I suggest to the Prime Minister that that is what he should do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) and the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) for making their maiden speeches on Tasmania. It has been excellent. They brought out a couple of very good points and I think that at a later date we should debate them. Unfortunately, they ruined things by bringing on this matter on a non-broadcasting day and on the eve of an election in Tasmania. Really, their motives have all gone astray. For that very reason I am afraid that we have to take a different tack and just tell them in a nice, polite way what has happened for Tasmania as a result of the representation it has had. The two honourable members from the Opposition said certain things but they did not have one word of praise for what has happened to Tasmania in the last seven years. Even the brilliant political strategists in Canberra all say that Tasmania has got far too much. Sometimes we are the centre of a joke here. The political commentators, honourable members on the other side and even some from our own side say: 'Not Tasmania again; you are not going to get another airport terminal down there?' Even the honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) cried out in the wilderness, saying: 'Look, a new terminal for Tasmania and we don't have one for Canberra'. Honourable members representing Tasmania have endured this sort of thing ever since they have been here.
—We are sick of it.

—We do get a bit sick of it. Even the 'dries' of our own party sneer at us. What happened in regard to Mount Lyell? There was nearly a fight because we wanted to save Mount Lyell for the ordinary people whom the honourable member for Henty mentioned, the ordinary workers. We fought dashed hard for those people and for the ordinary families at Mount Lyell but we were the subject of ridicule as a result of it. So, I say to honourable members: 'Please do not tell us that we do not care for the ordinary or average person of Tasmania'. We know all about them. After spending about seven years in this Parliament, it is most evident to me that the harder we try, the more achievements we obtain for our State, the more we are criticised. To me, that is foreign. Even some of the great political writers up here that I have heard about for so many years seem to ridicule us. If we try hard and fight hard we can be the subject of ridicule because we talk too much. I just cannot understand that. The honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) outlined in some detail the things that have come to Tasmania as a result of the Fraser Government. Even the media editorials-in the Age, the Australian and of course the Examiner and the Mercury-have detailed very succinctly the fact that we have certain things that other States do not have and that we had better tell the State Labor Government to stop whingeing about those things because it is exacerbating the ridicule that we suffer as a result of coming to Canberra and trying for the State of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that an election will occur in Tasmania on 15 May and we all know that the Opposition has to do something to create in the minds of the Tasmanian people a feeling that the State Labor Government is not too bad. But even on the day of the launching of the campaign the media reports said that there was a total absence of razzamatazz, a minimum of applause, no banner waving, no placards and no uninhibited cheering. In fact, it was a very subdued affair-many said it was a result of the fact that never before had there been a Premier so unpopular. Harry Holgate is not a bad bloke. But he has a rating of only 11 per cent-the lowest of any Premier ever known in Australia.

The Opposition has the audacity to try to move away from some of the things that have occurred in Tasmania. I will mention just a few. The honourable member for Braddon mentioned Electrona Carbide Industries Pty Ltd and the pyramids, which are a monument to the Honourable Bill Neilson, but a waste of money. Again , the Tasmanian College of Advanced Education cost $38m but is sitting up on the hill being wasted. Yet the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) has the audacity to say that we do not care for the ordinary people. I say to the honourable member that that money has been wasted. Tasmania has had good Labor Premiers. It had a Labor government for 43 years. Unfortunately, the nice looking Doug Lowe said: 'We will fight for Tasmania. We will win elections'. He certainly won the election, but what did he do for Tasmania? He procrastinated. He allowed the greenies and other people to come into the fray. They have ruined the economy of Tasmania as a result. All Tasmanians know about it. But unfortunately the situation has gone too far. Tasmania is in a perilous situation. As the honourable member for Henty said, the state of the economy there is bad. The level of unemployment is bad. We all know that, but it has been caused by inept, incompetent, stupid State politicians.

Unfortunately, Harry Holgate-as I mentioned, he is not a bad fellow-as leader must be saddled with the responsibilities. Everybody is blaming him. Unfortunately, he will go out on his ear as a result of earlier, poor government . So it is useless to bring up a matter of public importance that tries to blame the Federal Government for the waste and incompetence that have occurred in Tasmania. In fact, the people of Tasmania have been conned. Let us hope that at the next election, on 15 May, they will be very sensible and will vote for a government that they hope will bring them out of the mess they are in. Let us hope that they will forget about some of the independents, who are extremely selfish. All they have been saying is 'We want to save the South-West. We are not interested in anything else'. They are not interested in all the other problems that the honourable member for Henty mentioned. Their theme is: 'We will get our pay only for saving that river'. If that is not being irresponsible , selfish and trying to ruin the economy completely I do not know what is. So the people of Tasmania will have to watch very carefully some of the independents who are hell-bent on destroying not only the Labor Party but also the Liberal Party and, in fact, the people of Tasmania. I only hope that Robin Gray in his speech of, I believe, tomorrow night mentions that fact. I hope that Harry Holgate comes out and mentions that we do not want in Tasmania politicians who care for one little thing rather than for all the other problems that the honourable member for Henty has mentioned. The Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), who is at the table, is ridiculed at times because he said that he was a $50,000m member. In fact, at the next election he will be a $ 1,000m--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, $100,000m in capital works will be going into his electorate. I could go on. I get sick of praising these fellows up. What is the use? This matter of public importance, ladies and gentlemen, is a waste of time. The Opposition brought it up only to try to build up its little State Government in Tasmania, to boost its image. Unfortunately, the Opposition has gone too far. I do not want to be too critical but, because of the facts that I have mentioned, because of the selfish attitude of the independents down there, the economy of Tasmania could be ruined. Therefore, we will continue our fight. We will continue to fight as a team. My friend, the colonel, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), has just entered the chamber. The other day someone mentioned that he was doing a most adequate job. I agree. In Tasmania we need leaders and we certainly have one-the best-in the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members on this side of the chamber from Tasmania form a nice little team, a solid team whose members do not run each other down, do not knife each other in the back and are not jealous of each other's positions. We fight on that level. That is why we are the envy of the Opposition. That is why we are the envy of all Australians and of the media-they cannot separate us. We stick together and fight together. We will always fight for Tasmania together.

TALK.START.PARA: —The discussion is concluded.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. My memory slipped. I forgot to mention my very good friend and colleague, the honourable member for Wilmot (Mr Burr)--
—There is no point of order.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That Australian families will be seriously affected by the Budget announcements which include the raising of, or imposing of, Sales Tax on the many items which must be provided by parents for their children's schooling.
We condemn the proposals as a regressive tax measure which will seriously affect students.

Sales Tax increases will affect the price to parents of a variety of items including school clothing, school footwear, exercise books, books and magazines for reading purposes, stationery, sports equipment, and other school requisites and will seriously disadvantage parents who are already finding it difficult to provide essential educational items.
Your petitioners request that the Government will not impose any further tax on these items which are needed for the educational progress of Australia's students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Seal Pups
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the present hunt for Harp seals in Canada is carried out in a cruel and inhuman manner.
That the population of Harp seals has not been clearly shown to be increasing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government formally call on the Canadian Government to end the Harp seal hunt and use its constitutional powers to halt the importation into Australia of products derived from the Harp seal, Pagophilus croenlandicus.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Tobacco
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

that any increase in excise duty on cigarettes would be a further burden on smokers, would adversely affect employment in the tobacco manufacturing industry and aggravate the already high levels of inflation;
your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will reject any proposal for an increase in tobacco excise;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duffy and Mr Lloyd.

PETITION.TITLE: Perth Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that total annual aircraft movements into and out of Perth Airport are expected to more than double over the next fourteen years.
Your petitioners note that this will produce a dramatic increase in noise pollution in the surrounding suburbs, particularly those directly beneath flight paths.
Your petitioners further note that unlike Great Britain, Australia has no legislation to allow payments of compensation for injurious affection.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
(1) That the Minister for Transport implement a curfew banning traffic movements at Perth Airport between 11.00 p.m. and 6.00 a.m.
(2) That legislation be introduced to allow payment for injurious affection, including compensation for cost of insulation of private and public buildings.
(3) That the planned parallel runway be constructed immediately so as to direct air traffic over the non-residential area at Newburn.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Cloverdale North Post Office, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the Cloverdale North Post Office in Sydenham Street, Cloverdale WA is of great importance to the local community.
Your Petitioners note that in the surrounding area there is a very high proportion of pensioners. Many of these people do not have cars and some have difficulty using public transport.

Your petitioners further note that since the costs associated with running such a post office agency are very low Australia Post will make only small savings at the expense and great inconvenience of its customers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that all plans to close Cloverdale North post office be abandoned.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as has already been the case with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That if, as is likely, the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty years leases, they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests .

That it is also quite clear, on past evidence, that these interests will have the full backing of the Queensland government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government .

That the Commonwealth Government has the power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people under its constitutional powers since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your petitioners' sincere belief that it failed to act in 1976 and thus, failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self-management.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :
That Family Radio Ltd represents the largest single interest group in the community-i.e., Christians-who do not have a voice in public broadcasting commensurate with their representation.
That prime time access to existing broadcasts by Christian groups is virtually non-existent, and access at other times is fast disappearing.
That, by comparison with other capitals, Brisbane is entitled to at least one more category 'S' FM broadcasting licence.
That there appears to be no prospect of the release of further category 'S' FM licences in the near future for Brisbane.
That satisfactory fulfillment of the aims of Family Radio and its expansion can only be achieved by broadcasting in its own right under licence.

That Family Radio has a responsibility to the large support groups which have contributed substantially to its development, to achieve the aims in broadcasting and community work for which it was established.

That there is an urgent need for the kind of service and support that Family Radio can provide to other community groups through the particular type of integrated programming proposed by the company under a full-time licence.
And that pruned government resources are obviously insufficient to advance the development of public broadcasting as originally intended.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will support Family Radio's application for a broadcasting licence and will enable more category 'S' FM licences to be made available in Brisbane.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill which is currently before the House encompasses a wide variety of measures to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act. These amendments include provisions to deal with tax avoidance-both on an international scale and domestically through trusts-short term capital gains and gifts of art work. There are also provisions dealing with zone allowances, living away from home allowances for Service personnel, depreciation for the steel industry, deductions for gifts to certain charities and changes to the rebate provisions for medical expenses. It is obvious, therefore, that this is a very complex and lengthy piece of legislation. I note that this Bill alone proposes to add some 40 pages and 24 clauses to the Income Tax Assessment Act, an Act which has become increasingly subject to amendment in recent years and which is accordingly becoming increasingly incomprehensible. By my count between 1976 and 1981 over 40 Bills came before this House to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act and the Income Tax (Rates) Act. We have by now had to deal with around 700 pages of mostly complex legislation. The result is that the Income Tax Assessment Act alone now runs to over 1,000 pages. Unfortunately, the flurry of activity over the last six years has contributed little towards improving the equity and efficiency-it certainly has not added to the simplicity -of our tax system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Act has now reached the stage where it is urgently necessary to consider conducting a comprehensive inquiry into the structure and form of the Act with a view to an extensive rewrite of the major provisions. With the overriding aim to improve equity and efficiency, this recasting should aim at simplifying the Act wherever possible. This would reduce compliance costs on the part of both the taxing authorities and taxpayers. Most importantly, a considerable simplification would remove many loopholes which are the fertile breeding ground of tax avoidance. This would in turn enable tax reductions to be made for the great majority of wage and salary earners who currently bear the burden of tax losses caused by the tax avoiders.

The Fraser Government must bear the blame for the drastic deterioration of the Act since it took office. Four factors have contributed to this development. Firstly, this Government has almost totally ignored the recommendations of the Asprey Committee, which committee-established by the previous Labor Government- formulated an extensive program to reform our tax system. Many of the Committee' s recommendations were worthy of much closer consideration than they have received at the hands of this Government. Secondly, the Government's failure to encompass fully retrospective legislation against blatant tax avoidance schemes has meant a constant flood of extremely complex anti-avoidance legislation. Much of it is to close up loopholes which have been created by earlier anti-avoidance legislation. As I have already said, the complexity of such legislation often serves only to spawn even more tax avoidance schemes. Careful and selective use of fully retrospective legislation will put an end to tax avoidance once and for all and stop the eternal merry-go-round of the Australian Taxation Office chasing the tax avoider with no lasting success.

Third, we have the large number of tax concessions awarded by this Government to various vested interest groups. On my reckoning we have had over 40 new concessions granted since 1976. While some such concessions are justified, their cost is invariably hidden. Usually they are totally inequitable and mostly there is no way of knowing whether they are proving effective in meeting their stated purpose. Finally, we have the conscious restructuring of the tax scales to give tax cuts to the wealthy at the expense of higher taxes for the great majority of taxpayers. These effects have been exacerbated by the failure to fully index the tax scales against inflation. This has pushed all taxpayers into higher average tax rates and has subjected many low income earners to tax for the first time. These are the policy decisions by which the Government has destroyed the equity, efficiency and simplicity of Australia's tax system. It has done so to such an extent that most taxpayers are overwhelmed by the tax laws and have little, if any, faith in their operations. An incoming Labor government will, as a first priority, reverse these sorts of developments. An essential first step in recreating an understood and workable tax system must be the sort of inquiry which I mentioned earlier.

I propose now to look at the specific provisions of the Bill. Many are relatively insignificant. I do not propose to deal with them at length in order that I may devote the majority of my speech to what I regard as by far the most important proposal; this is-I am sure the House will agree-the proposal to insert a new Division 13 into the principal Act. This new Division is to be enacted to replace the existing section 136 in order to combat tax avoidance on the international scale-mainly by transnational corporations-through the device known as transfer pricing. Transnational corporations have experienced phenomenal growth in the post-war era and now extend a major influence over the international economy. Direct foreign investment throughout the world by United States of America corporations, for example, trebled during the 1950s and again during the 1960s. Most of this was accounted for by transnational corporations. Japanese and West German direct foreign investment grew at similarly rapid rates . By the end of the 1970s transnational corporations controlled between a quarter and a third of all world production while total sales by foreign affiliates of transnational corporations were estimated at around $850 billion. By this time there was a total of 11,000 transnational corporations with 82,000 affiliates or subsidiaries world wide, of which about three-quarters were in the developed industrial nations.

Much of the international trade which these vast corporations conduct goes on within their own organisations-between the parent firm and its affiliates or between separate affiliates. This extensive intra-firm trade has been estimated by the authoritative Brandt report on international development issues to make up around one third of all world trade. In addition, a wide range of other transactions take place extensively between the different parts of these enterprises including, for example, the granting of loans, the licensing of technology and the provision of other services. It is little wonder that this web of transactions between affiliates of powerful corporations, and the ability which it creates for such corporations to manipulate financial flows, has become a major concern to governments world wide. Clearly the interests of a corporation which seeks to maximise its global profits will differ from the interests of host countries which attempt to maximise their national benefits from that corporation's activities. Nowhere is this conflict more in evidence than in the potential losses of tax revenue which may result from such corporations undertaking transfer pricing operations.

Transfer pricing basically involves corporations fixing prices for goods, services, capital or technology transferred between members of the group at an artificially determined level, which is not ralated to true market prices, to ensure that profits are made in countries with the lowest tax rates-or sometimes in countries where no tax is levied at all. Such a profit shifting arrangement was revealed last year in the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation case which was heard by the High Court of Australia. In this example of transfer pricing, the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation, which was indirectly owned by Kaiser Aluminium of the United States and Rio Tinto Zinc Corporation Ltd of the United Kingdom, contracted to sell bauxite to Japanese buyers. Rather than selling directly to Japan, the sale was carried out through an interposed company in Hong Kong which was jointly owned by Commonwealth Aluminium and the Japanese buyers. The Hong Kong company's only function was to buy bauxite from Australia at around 33 shillings a ton and then resell it to Japan at 40 shillings.

No physical transactions took place in this part of the deal. The Hong Kong company recorded only book entries while the bauxite was delivered directly from Australia to Japan. In this way profits which would normally have accrued to the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation in Australia, and have been taxed accordingly in this country, accrued instead in Hong Kong where they were taxed at low rates -the company tax rates there are about 15 per cent to 17 per cent-and the proceeds were split between the partners in the Hong Kong company. It has been estimated that Australia lost almost $3.5m in tax revenue out of this arrangement. The Taxation Office had no power to stop this massive revenue loss because section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act-our supposed anti-transfer pricing section-was again found wanting by a compliant High Court which continued its dubious record of supporting the tax avoiders against the best interests of all Australians. That was the record until very recently. Yet it was not as though the tax office and the Government had not been warned about the deficiencies of section 136, but I will say more on that in a moment.

Details of another transfer pricing arrangement were revealed at around the same time as the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation case. This involved the subsidiary of another transnational corporation. According to reports at the time, Swiss Aluminium Australia, which is a major partner in the Gove venture in the Northern Territory, recorded a total trading surplus of over $122m over an eight-year period, but paid only negligible income tax. By contrast, its minority partner in the venture, Gove Alumina Ltd paid $5.7m tax in 1979-80 alone on pre-tax earnings of $11.1m. These results seem extraordinary and even more so in the light of allegations by the Government of Iceland that Swiss Aluminium's parent company, Alusuisse, understated the profits from its Icelandic smelter by $US47.5m over a period of seven years due to transfer pricing transactions involving purchases of bauxite from Australia. These transactions apparently involved increases in the price of bauxite at sea of over 50 per cent. Should these reports be correct, there is little likelihood, given the record of the courts, that the present provisions of the tax legislation will result in successful action to recover any tax avoided by the company.

I am sure these two examples represent but the tip of the iceberg in abuse of Australia's tax system through international transactions. Australia is particularly vulnerable to this type of arrangement. We are a relatively wealthy nation, offering substantial rewards for transnational corporations' operations in this country. We are rich in mineral resources, our extractive and secondary industries are dominated by foreign based transnational corporations and we have a government which has for years adopted a wholeheartedly open approach to foreign investment regardless of cost or the greater national interest. The transnational corporations which have come to dominate our extractive industries especially tend to be vertically integrated and provide the major source of advanced expertise in exploration, extraction and processing of petroleum and minerals. In some areas, such as alumina, no reliable open market price exists for their product, making transfer pricing-type arrangements extremely difficult to detect.

Most of the transnational corporations involved have built up over many years enormous knowledge and expertise regarding international financial transactions and tax systems and obviously have learned to exploit this knowledge to their greatest benefit. Of course, this is not to say that all transnational corporations are immersed in the mire of tax avoidance. I am sure that many aspire to be acceptable corporate citizens. However, the rewards are great and, as is shown by experience in Europe-where advanced nations have reportedly paid out hundreds of millions of dollars in transferred prices on petroleum and pharmaceutical products in recent years-Australia cannot afford to be complacent and not take every possible precaution to prevent this type of activity.

It is important at this stage to examine briefly just what instruments are available to our taxing authorities to combat such abuses. The current powers which exist to control international tax avoidance fall into four areas: The Banking Act and system of tax clearance certificates to control the use of tax havens; Australia's double tax treaties to prevent international double taxation ; the new general anti-avoidance section introduced as Part IVA of the principal Act last year; and, finally, section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which is being amended in the Bill before the House. I will deal briefly with these in turn.

Firstly, the tax treatment of persons and companies involved in dealings with tax havens is important. Tax havens are countries which levy little or no tax on certain income and which usually have minimal, if any, companies and securities requirements. Also tax havens usually offer an effective cloak of secrecy to potential users. These characteristics make the use of tax havens very attractive to potential tax avoiders and pose significant problems for taxing authorities. Such havens are often used by international corporations as part of their transfer pricing operations. For example, they may set up a holding company in any one of a number of low tax countries to collect income in one form or another from world-wide operations and, after it has been subjected to nominal tax, redistribute it in the form of loans, for example for the continuing use of members of the groups.

A European Economic Commission report in the mid-1970s stated that there were some 2,000 holding companies registered in Luxembourg, 20,000 in Liechtenstein and 10,000 in Switzerland-all recognised tax havens. Another method is for transnational corporations to use provisions of double tax treaties which limit witholding tax on royalties to route such payments for the use of patents, know- how and copyright through tax havens. Further arrangements involve payment for leasing equipment to tax havens, the use of off-shore banking activities, the establishment of captive insurance companies-1,000 such companies exist in Bermuda alone-or the registration of shipping fleets in countries such as Liberia and Panama. It would take hours to deal with the intricacies of such arrangements.

However, I have indicated the types of problems which exist. Control of this type of activity is an essential element of a policy effectively to control transfer pricing. Australia's weapons in this area are nowhere near effective. Consequently, the use of tax havens by both individuals and companies to avoid Australian tax is rife. The major defect in this area is the lack of a foreign tax credit system to subject to tax in Australia income earned by Australians overseas. Currently, such income, if it is being taxed overseas at even minimal rates, is in most cases exempt from further local tax. The Banking Act and the system of tax clearance certificates which were designed to stop the use of tax havens have, for a number of reasons which I do not have time to go into now, proved ineffective. There is thus an urgent need to move towards adopting a system of foreign tax credits as an integral part of a comprehensive attack on international tax avoidance. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) proposed such a scheme in 1978 but backed down quickly under pressure from business. A Labor government most certainly would not capitulate to such self-interested lobbying.

Double tax treaties, of which Australia currently has 12 in place, are designed to facilitate international flows of trade and capital by eliminating double taxation. Most aspects of Australia's treaties substantially reflect the principles of the model double tax convention of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and, in doing so, have facilitated the development of our financial and trading dealings with overseas countries. However, there is a need to examine closely the possibility which I mentioned earlier that transnational corporations are using the limitation imposed on withholding taxes on dividends and royalties paid overseas to exploit our tax system. Possibly the most significant aspect of our treaties, especially given the problems I have outlined, is the section modelled after article 9 of the model OECD agreement which allows the reconstruction of profits of associated entities which have obviously been engaging in transfer pricing activities. This provision has generally been regarded as a more effective weapon against transfer pricing than the current section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act because the provisions of the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act prevail over the ordinary provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. However, as the use of this section is limited to treaty countries, and of the many recognised tax havens we have a treaty only with Switzerland, its usefulness is very limited and in no way precludes effective action in all the other areas I have mentioned.

The second important element in our tax treaties is that section which authorises the co-operation and exchange of information between the taxing authorities in each country. One of the major obstacles which face taxing authorities world-wide in dealing with transfer pricing is their inability to obtain accurate and reliable information in sufficient detail to enable them to untangle the web which transnational corporations often wind around their operations. To overcome transfer pricing in Australia, the Australian Taxation Office will need a substantial amount of reliable information about the activities of transnational corporations in many countries. While the tax treaty provisions-which I understand have been used to some degree-provide access to a certain amount of information, it is abundantly clear that it is nowhere near enough to allow the Taxation Office effectively to use the new powers which this Bill will provide.

What is needed in Australia is the enactment of a code of conduct to be observed by transnational corporations which involves, among other things, the provision of wide-ranging information to host governments. Guidelines formulated by the OECD, for example, require transnational corporations to disclose detailed information on their structure, operations of affiliates, areas of operation, employment, sales, pricing and investment policies and accounting procedures. Such guidelines in force in Australia would provide the Taxation Office with much of the information necessary to overcome transfer pricing. It is scandalous that this Government, obviously beholden to financial support from large corporations, has failed to take this absolutely necessary action even though such action has been strongly recommended by the OECD, which is hardly the most radical body. I doubt whether the Taxation Office will be able effectively to use its new powers under Division 13 introduced by this legislation unless it has available the sort of information which such a code of conduct would provide. I can assure the House that a Labor government will not shirk from ensuring that transnational corporations meet such requirements.

Next in the armoury of weapons against international tax avoidance is the new general anti-tax avoidance section introduced last year as Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Part IVA applies to any scheme from which a taxpayer obtains a tax benefit, whether that scheme has been entered into or carried out in Australia, outside Australia or partly in Australia and partly outside Australia. Seemingly this would apply to transfer-pricing type arrangements but obviously the Government prefers specific legislation in this vital area, with the provisions of Part IVA as a fallback position, remembering of course that the provisions of Part IVA have yet to be tested.

I now come to the most direct weapon against transfer pricing-section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This section has a long history, originating from section 28 of the Income Tax Assessment Act of 1922. Broadly, this section operates so that, in the case of overseas controlled companies operating in Australia which produce either no taxable income or less than the amount of income which might be expected to arise from that business, the Commissioner of Taxation may determine a level of taxable profits which he regards as reasonable , given the nature of that business. On the face of it, this section seems to provide clear powers to deal with transfer pricing yet, like so many other sections of the tax Act, it has been rendered virtually meaningless by successive court decisions culminating in the High Court decision in the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation case, to which I referred earlier.

I might briefly point out that the deficiencies in section 136 have not just been revealed in the past few months. Indeed, it has been known from as far back as 1942 that certain problems existed in relation to this section and in 1975 the Asprey Taxation Review Committee pointed out precisely the defects which the High Court seized on in its recent decision. The Committee regarded the section as totally inadequate and recommended that it be replaced. Yet the Government ignored the Committee's findings and took no action whatsoever to meet the expected consequences. Since 1978 the Opposition has continually called for substantial revisions to section 136 but for two years these warnings fell on deaf ears. It was not until 1980 the the Government first indicated that it would look at revising the section, and it has taken a further two years to come up with the current proposals. It is now seven years since Asprey pointed out, in detail, the considerable loopholes in this section. Who knows how many hundreds of millions of dollars in tax revenue have been lost in this time because of the negligence of this Government?

Briefly, the weaknesses exposed in section 136 centre on the problem of defining a business which is 'controlled principally by non-residents' as set out in paragraph (a) of section 136. This paragraph could be easily avoided if a majority of shares were vested in residents, with a provision that those shares carry only a small fraction of rights or limited voting powers. Alternatively, as happened in the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation case, the operation of this paragraph could be prevented merely by having a majority, of Australian directors on the board, regardless of the fact that they may act solely in the interests of the company's foreign owners. Again as happened in the CAC case, paragraphs (b) and (c) of section 136 could be avoided by interposing a second company incorporated and resident in Australia but owned principally by foreigners for the purpose of holding the shares in the taxpayer company. Finally, with regard to section 136 the Commissioner is not given any specific powers and is severely limited in his ability to reconstruct a true level of taxable income from the transfer pricing arrangemens.

These, then, are the defects which have scuttled all attempts to date to stop transfer pricing through the use of section 136. In framing its new section, I am glad to say the Government has obviously taken note of Asprey's warnings and subsequent court decisions and has adopted an entirely new basis of attack. Certainly we regard this new approach as much more likely to succeed than its predecessor and promise the Government the full weight of Labor's support in its endeavours to stamp out such objectionable practices.

The proposed Division 13 does not depend on basic tests of control or share ownership. Instead, the Commissioner will be authorised to apply the section where goods or services are supplied or acquired under an international agreement, where he is satisfied that any of the parties involved were not dealing at arm's length with each other and where the consideration involved is other than could be expected from independent persons dealing at arm's length. Where these tests apply the Commissioner will have much wider powers to reconstruct a true level of taxable income. Basically, the Commissioner will be required to use the 'arm's length principle' which refers to the consideration which might reasonably be expected to have passed between independent parties. This has become an accepted international principle for dealing with transfer- pricing situations: For example, it is used in the United States of America; it is the basis for Australia's double tax agreements; and it was recommended in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's guidelines on this problem put out in 1979.

In some situations, however, it is not possible to determine an arm's length price. There may, for example, be a tightly controlled market with no directly comparable transactions between independent enterprises, or such data may not be available to taxing authorities. In this situation other methods need to be used to determine an arm's length price and the proposed section, rightly in our view , provides wide scope for the Commissioner to arrive at an appropriate level of taxable income. He may use any one of a number of alternatives. For example, he may use the cost plus basis which starts from the cost of producing the goods and services and adds whatever cost and profit mark-up is acceptable. Alternatively, he may use the so-called retail price method by starting at the final selling price and subtracting the cost and appropriate profit mark-up. Other methods are available, but these are the most commonly recommended. Of course, the Commissioner's calculations can be challenged in the courts, but at least legislative guidelines are to be provided, which is a big improvement over the present situation.

There are two further aspects of this new Division 13 to which I wish briefly to refer. Firstly, I congratulate the Government on adopting in regard to this Division a principle which Labor strongly advocated last year when this House was considering the new general anti-avoidance section, Part IVA, but which the Government refused to accept. The operation of Part IVA in our view was unduly restricted by applying only to schemes where tax avoidance could be seen to be the dominant purpose. This left untouched many schemes entered into for various purposes, but with undoubted tax avoidance implications, thus opening scope to avoid the operation of Part IVA. It now seems that the Government has realised that this approach is ill-advised and it intends that Division 13 should not be so restricted. Indeed it has adopted a very liberal approach to its operation. To quote the Treasurer's second reading speech:

'. . . the fact that tax saving is not a key purpose of a particular arrangement or transaction is no reason why we, as a nation, should not be in a position to counteract any loss to the Australian revenue inherent in it'.

These sentiments are thoroughly commendable and, I would think, just as commendable in the case of Part IVA where they do not exist. I can only hope that the Treasurer now intends to rethink his approach to Part IVA. My second concluding point on this aspect is one of criticism rather than praise. I find the approach to penalties associated with Division 13 to be curious indeed. I will have more to say about that during the Committee stage. But basically we regard the 10 per cent penalty as being absurdly low.

In the time available I would like to refer briefly to two other amendments in this Bill. The amendment to section 26AAA is very important. Section 26AAA basically says that capital profits derived from the sale of property within 12 months of its purchase shall be included in assessable income and taxed accordingly. This section was initially introduced to overcome defects in the other section designed to tax capital gains, that is section 26 (a), where it was found almost impossible to prevent the intention by the taxpayer of profit making. From the outset section 26AAA was easily avoided by holding the assets for one day more than 12 months before selling. It became apparent several years ago that more loopholes had been found through the section and drastic changes were necessary.

The most public illustration of the problems with this section was in April last year when Mr Holmes a Court's Bell Group of companies avoided its operation and made a spectacular tax free profit of $16.5m from its aborted takeover bid for Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd. During March last year the Bell Group quickly accumulated almost 20 per cent of shares in Elders. When, however, its takeover bid was blocked by unnamed friends of Elders, the Bell Group called off its bid and unloaded the shares at a $16.5m profit. Normally, such a profit would be taxable under section 26AAA but in this case the shares were held not by the Bell group directly but in an empty shell company with few other assets. When the bid was called off the shares themselves were not sold but rather the shell company, a subsidiary of the Bell Group, which had been owned for more than 12 months and therefore tax was avoided.

There has been some speculation that this profit could be taxed under section 25 of the Act if the Bell Group was in the business of profit making from takeover bids or under section 26 (a) as part of a profit-making undertaking or scheme. Neither of these sections seems readily applicable, if as seems the case , a genuine takeover bid was involved and Bell did not make a continuing business of this sort of operation. Certainly, these claims do not preclude effective action directly in the section 26AAA area. Of course, there have been other examples both by the Bell Group and the Bond Corporation of avoidance of this section. I do not have time to pursue the debate any further. I therefore move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
whilst not opposing the Bill, the House is of the opinion that it is deficient in that-

(1) penalties contained in the Bill for participation in transfer pricing type tax avoidance arrangements are insufficient to provide suitable deterrents against tax avoidance and are inconsistent with penalties contained elsewhere in the Act;

(2) without the accompanying adoption of a code of conduct for transnational corporations, as recommended by the OECD and the United Nations, the effectiveness of Division 13 is likely to be limited by the difficulty confronting the Taxation Commissioner in obtaining adequate information;
(3) the Bill fails to take retrospective action against persons flouting the tax system through the blatant avoidance schemes utilising section 26AAA of the Act; and
(4) the Bill endorses use by the medical profession of corporate and trust arrangements with significant tax avoidance implications.
