SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make a few remarks about personal taxation. There would not be anyone in this House-there would probably not be anyone in Australia-who does not believe that personal taxation is too high. That has been acknowledged by Government and Opposition alike. The problem, of course, is how to reduce that taxation responsibility and at the same time provide enough money for the Government to conduct its affairs. But I believe it is the most important problem we face and it must be tackled in this coming Budget or before. Personal tax reform is badly needed in order to restore incentive to business and industry and personal work habits, to ease the excessive wage demands and to increase employment by inducing employers to expand their businesses. It is regrettable that the only industry to benefit from high personal taxation is the leisure industry. People leave the work force because they believe it is not worth it to pay the Government up to 60 per cent of their earnings in taxation. They would rather rearrange their affairs, perhaps with less income, and move into a leisure situation or a part time work situation in which they work less and enjoy themselves more.

As I have mentioned, the problem is to reduce responsibly personal taxation. Apart from reducing the amount of taxation, about which I have spoken before, I believe that one of the great stumbling blocks for people in the present scheme is the three-tier taxation system. The leaps between these tiers are just too great. They go from 32 cents in the dollar, to 46 cents and then to 60 cents. I recommend that we return to a graduated scale where the rises are less steep. We used to have seven or eight tiers. It was said at the time that the scheme was too complicated but I do not believe it was. It was a simple scheme. At the end of the tax year people looked at the scale and saw the tax they had to pay. It was not difficult at all. What happens now, of course, is that when people are edging up to the next tax bracket they move heaven and earth to avoid moving into it. If it were a graduated scale, as it used to be, I do not believe people would worry so much. They would work hard to expand their businesses and maximise their incomes and where they finished up at the end of the year would not be of such great concern.

Discussion of a graduated tax scale leads to the question of flat rate tax-that is, the abolition of scales and the adoption of a flat rate tax. I do not want to dwell particularly on this question but it is an attractive scheme. There is no doubt about it. But when we look into it a little what we will do by adopting a flat rate tax is throw out the window a basic philosophy which I believe most of us on this side of the House hold, that is, that higher income earners pay a higher rate of tax. For this reason I reject a flat rate tax as unjust and inequitable. It disadvantages the lower income earners, and they are the bulk of the taxpayers. For example, according to the 1981 Budget figures, 4.8 million Australians were in the 32 cent bracket, 686,000 odd were in the 46 cent bracket and 48,000 were in the 60 cent bracket. I am not supporting those brackets, as I have already said. What I am saying is that the great bulk of Australian taxpayers are in the lowest tax bracket and a flat tax would badly disadvantage those people. These figures showing where the tax burden falls must be taken into account in any personal taxation revision. I certainly hope that that revision will not be too long in coming.

I urge the Government to be positive and bold in its approach to tax reform and not to fiddle around with the system or just fiddle around the edges. It must give demonstrable relief to Australians, particularly those who are caught in the pay-as-you-earn system. It is these people who are clearly approaching the point where their personal tax burden is becoming a load too heavy to bear. To effect a reduction in tax will necessitate some other form of income for the Government and I would strongly support the expansion of an indirect tax base.

I turn now to the question of tax avoidance. This legislation is designed to eliminate a section of the tax avoidance industry. While tax avoidance is larger than anyone would like to see, I do not believe that any Treasurer has done more than the present Treasurer (Mr Howard) to attempt to eliminate it. I believe that that should be acknowledged. With any fairness, it will be acknowledged by both sides of the House. Many holes remain to be plugged and I sincerely hope that this will be done. There is no justice in some people paying tax and others , who are on high incomes or reasonable incomes, paying little or no tax. There are many who should be paying their share of tax who are not. Take, for example, a man generally known as the leader of this tax avoidance system in Australia, Mr Peter Clyne, who dodges in and out of the country like a rabbit. He comes here and openly boasts about how he pays no tax. He gives expensive advice to others on how do to the same thing. While he is here, of course, he makes full use of all our facilities, our public services, our roads and our transport system. Does he consider that he is liable to share any of this burden? Not Mr Clyne. I have no doubt that if he were hit by a bus he would be the first person to want to use a public hospital. Others carry the burden and he reaps the benefits. Of course, he is not the only person involved. It is with some sense of gratification that I see that Mr Clyne has eventually been nailed. I understand it is unlikely that we will see him back in this country. Tax minimisation is legitimate and we all do it to reduce our tax to as low an amount as possible. Nobody wants to pay more tax. But those who are on high or reasonable incomes and pay no tax are a different kettle of fish altogether, be they companies or individuals. Such action cannot be justified or defended in any way.

I give an honourable mention to another group-those who are using the cash economy to the full and who do not pay any tax. In some areas-this applied particularly to my electorate until some months ago-it is difficult, almost impossible, to get tradesmen to work unless they receive cash in hand. Again, a sector of the community is escaping its fair burden. I believe the Government must look at this cash economy evasion. Unfortunately, I can see only one remedy to the situation with tradesmen-that is, the registration of all subcontractors. Under that system, if someone were to go to an employer, seek work and be put on , the employer would be obliged to ask for his registration number. If he were not registered as a subcontractor the employer would be obliged to deduct his tax at source. If the employer did not do that penalties against both the employer and the employee would have to be considered. Nobody likes less than I do to advocate registering anybody. On the other hand, I fail to see why we should condone the actions of a significant sector of the community which is escaping its burden of tax.

Of course, an argument which is fairly widely canvassed is that the high level of personal taxation which is rampant in this country is forcing honest men to become rogues. I must say that I have a certain sympathy for that argument, but I come back to one basic point: There is a law which states that we must pay a certain amount of tax. That law should stand. No law states that everyone should share the burden but that is what we must do if we are to have equality and justice in our tax system. I believe we have a responsibility to obey that law and to pay our taxes, although we may not like doing it very much. If we do not pay our fair share some people, particularly those caught in the pay-as-you-earn system, will carry a disproportionate burden of taxation. This Bill will further ensure, particularly in the company taxation area, that the burden falls equitably not only on those who do not have the desire, the means or the opportunity to avoid paying their share of tax but also on those who are now avoiding paying their share. I conclude with the observation that Australian society is divisive enough without the artificial division of inequitable tax. For that reason, because it is a step in what I believe is the right direction, I strongly support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to underline some of the things that the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) suggested before he left the chamber. I think the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill is extremely important. In terms of taxation it is perhaps one of the most important pieces of legislation to come into the House. It is unfortunate that there appears to be little enthusiasm on the part of honourable members opposite for full scale debate on this measure. Of course, the matter of transfer pricing arises because of broader characteristics of international economies and because of the existence of transnational corporations and their dominance on the international scene. In no area of economic theory, in my view, is the Government's rhetoric- particularly the rhetoric of the so-called free traders or dries within the Government-more out of touch with reality than it is in this field of international economics. Those people believe-presumably, as they support the Treasurer (Mr Howard) who believes also-that trade in the modern world takes place within the context of competitive markets subject to laws of supply and demand; that is, it is a world in which one can sensibly talk about arm's length trading in which those countries which participate, as a result of the operations of the market, receive perhaps a fair share of the fruits.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) pointed out, the existence of intra-firm trade-that is, trade within various arms of the same corporate network-on a massive scale destroys such illusory, even fanciful, views of the world. The real world is increasingly dominated by very large corporations or clusters of corporations which often conduct their principal transactions within their own vertically integrated structures. Putting it simply, they trade with themselves. It is this reality, so briefly referred to by the Treasurer in his second reading speech, which gives rise to the need for international tax avoidance or transfer pricing. This, as the honourable member for Gellibrand suggested, is the practice of transferring goods, services, capital or technology in such a way that profits are made as low as possible in those nations with the highest tax rates. It is not a new phenomenon. In 1975 the Asprey Taxation Review Committee suggested that section 136, as it was then drafted, was inadequate and that that section needed to be redrafted. If this Government, even in the last few years, had been as committed as it claimed it was to doing something about tax avoidance where it affects major corporations it would have done something about it before now. It has had seven years. It was really only after the High Court of Australia brought down a judgment against the Government in the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation case last year that finally the Government gave in and introduced this legislation. But it is not a new issue; it is not a new problem. The United States Tariff Commission, in a report in 1973, pointed to the dangers. It stated:
The chief strategy of tax minimisation by international companies is manipulation of transfer prices.
It stated further:
The prevalence of administered or arbitrary intra corporate pricing is a principal reason why multinational companies prefer 100 per cent ownership of foreign subsidiaries.

The problem, of course, of transfer pricing includes more than the matter of a tax. Allowed to flourish it results not only in a loss of tax revenue to the Government but also in a loss of what would otherwise be higher wages to workers and a loss of profits to local shareholders. It results in an increase in the profits of the transitional corporations. It has very serious impacts, for example, on Australia's balance of payments. It causes a loss of foreign exchange. I stress that when we consider this issue we need to look at it within a certain economic context. As Galbraith pointed out in the Modern Economy, the state, in dealing with transnational capital, is confronting not a market on which it seeks to impose order but an alternative planning system with which it must compete for power. When speaking of the United States, Galbraith said:

In the place of the market system, we must now assume for approximately half of all economic output there is a planning system. The planning system consists in the United States of at least 2,000 large corporations. In their transactions they have power that transcends the market.

In Australia no doubt the top 200 firms fulfil a similar role as an alternative source of power and economic planning to that of governments. I want to spend some time dealing with a particular example of such corporate power which is extremely relevant to this issue. Indeed, the two examples cited in the speech of the honourable member for Gellibrand were drawn from the aluminium industry. I want to speak particularly about the nature and character of that industry, and why transfer pricing is likely to occur in it.

Firstly, one ought to underline the fact that this industry is highly oligopolistic; that is, it is dominated by six transnational corporations, sometimes referred to as the six sisters, which are vertically integrated through all stages of production and which own or control more than half of the world's productive capacity, including each of the three basic stages of production. They are, in approximate order of importance, Alcoa, Alcan, Reynolds , Kaiser, Pechiney and the Swiss Aluminium Co. Each is involved, either on its own or in partnership with other producers, in virtually every bauxite and alumina plant of any importance outside the centrally planned economies. All of these companies are operating in Australia and, one way or another, have a controlling interest in every major proposal in the industry at the various stages of the industry. As the Treasury pointed out in its submission to the Senate inquiry:

Not only are all phases of the aluminium industry effectively owned and controlled by (these) foreign corporations, but foreign ownership extends beyond equity in the various phases of the industry to include shares in reserves and output, to the extent that 'about two-thirds of estimated total resources of major bauxite deposits currently in production are ''owned'' by foreign customers and a similar proportion of the production from existing alumina projects is owned by foreign customers'.
I underline the word 'customers'. The submission continues:
Similarly, aluminium smelters constructed or in the course of construction, are all controlled by these major corporations.

As the International Bauxite Association has pointed out, the expansion of the aluminium industry in Australia, under the control of the so-called six sisters, is the principal factor preventing the development of more open and competitive international trading in aluminium and therefore a more genuine marketing system . In an extensive study titled 'Ownership and Control: The Changing Structure of the Bauxite, Alumina and Primary Aluminium Industries over the period 1961-1982' , the IBA concluded that while there may have been some slackening of control by the aluminium majors due to the creation of 'State-owned companies in Western Europe to control a certain share of primary aluminium in these countries', access to control by these major corporations of the Australian industry has been the most important single factor going in the opposite direction; that is, maintaining the control of the so-called six sisters over the Australian industry. Australia, by allowing dominance of the major companies in its expanding industry, has been assisting the preservation of an international oligopoly rather than assisting to produce a more open trading situation. I hope that some of the so-called dries within the Liberal Party will have a look at this situation in terms of how it lines up with their philosophy.

The concentration and control were acknowledged by the Treasurer in introducing this legislation-the particular measures on which I am concentrating my remarks are in proposed new Division 13 of Part III of the Act-designed to combat transfer pricing in this and in other vertically integrated industries. There is in the aluminium industry little arm's length trading, because one is dealing essentially with a corporate planning system, not a market system. This fact was pointed out in yesterday's Age newspaper in a report concerning the Sumitomo company's cancellation of an order for alumina from Gove. David Uren, who wrote the report, commented:

Most smelters buy their alumina either in house or on long term contracts and there has only ever been a marginal spot market. With the reduction in smelter capacity world-wide, smelters are taking no more than their contracted tonnage ( of alumina)-that is, the market gets to be eliminated.
This problem goes to the heart of the amendments proposed to section 136. To quote the Treasurer:

Where the Commissioner of Taxation determines that the new provisions should apply, arm's length prices will be substituted for income tax purposes in place of those adopted in the profit shifting arrangements.

But I ask the question, taking this industry as an example: What will be the relevance of 'arm's length prices' when the industry is so tightly controlled that one can argue that such prices do not really exist? How will one determine the appropriate price of metal moving from Boyne Island to the new subsidiary of Conzinc Rio Tinto of Australia, Showa Denko in Japan, of which CRA recently purchased a half share? Looking at the domestic pricing situation, there is no agreement about the basis of price fixing for ingot in Australia, where the companies have charged the same price for ingot and where the local price bears no necessary relationship to international prices. This much was established at the aborted Prices Justification Tribunal inquiry last year.

We must recognise that while it is very good that this legislation has been passed and that we have a new revamped section 136, and no doubt there will be some flexibility to look at various ways of determining what arm's length prices might mean, when we are confronted with highly integrated industries that control so much of world production that they are able to arrange prices between themselves, there will be real problems with determining what the so-called arm' s length price is about.

Is it not also time that we recognised that pricing itself is as much a political decision as it is an economic decision? Australian prices for bauxite, for example, have been determined very largely by political factors. This much was recognised by the IBA in its study of bauxite prices published in November 1979. That study concluded that:

Australia, as the largest producer of bauxite in the world, exerts the largest influence on markets for metallurgical ore and consequently upon alumina-that exports of bauxite are not publicly reported but are sold at low prices and that much of the Australian alumina has been produced at low cost, relative to other countries, and sold at the lowest reported price in the world.

The IBA report indicates that benefits to this country as opposed to the companies have been minimal because royalties have been ridiculously low, with taxation being amongst the lowest level of revenue per tonne of bauxite received by the various governments from private companies. Not only are taxes ridiculously low by world standards; our will to collect taxes from the companies appears to be extremely weak. For example, the Treasurer, in an answer to a question from me last November, revealed that the Taxation Office did not receive bauxite and alumina export data, even though the information was supplied to Ministers and other Government bodies such as the Bureau of Customs and the Department of Trade and Resources. Perhaps this is why it was the Icelandic Government and not the Australian Government which drew attention to the massive difference between the price of alumina leaving the company at Gove and that entering the related company in Iceland. The Taxation Office perhaps did not have at its disposal all the relevant information, and certainly was not being encouraged to seek it. The Government is to be congratulated that seven years on it has now at least implemented the Asprey committee's recommendation that section 136 should be rewritten to empower the Commissioner of Taxation to:
reconstruct the profits of non-residents derived from sources in Australia and the profits of residents dealing with associated non-residents.

It is important that the arm's length principle be accepted and applied to this area of transfer pricing. It is quite amazing that the Asprey Taxation Review Committee could have pointed out seven years ago what the High Court's judgment would be when a case was tested. This Government, which claims that it is interested in tax avoidance, had that report and did not act upon it until a company was found out, and then it was not able to be properly dealt with by the courts because appropriate amendments had not been drafted. One does not have much sympathy for the High Court because one knows what the High Court, in many respects, has been about; it has been about striking down legislation in this area in terms of extremely narrow interpretations. The Government had been warned but it had done nothing. But at least one can say that the Government has now finally acted and that the revisions to be carried out, in terms of the legislation at least, go some of the way towards dealing with the problem.

But one ought to go on to point out that the legislation itself certainly will not be enough. There are weaknesses in the legislation. I think the penalties that are suggested represent more interest in taxes not paid rather than in any severe penalty. If the Government were really seriously interested in taking on the question of transfer pricing one would expect it to put into the Act very much stronger penalties. When we deal with these companies we are dealing, as I have suggested, with a planning system. If we are not prepared to put massive resources into the Taxation Office to seek information, we will not get very much more money out of these companies, because they are highly sophisticated organisations.

One can add to that comment the suggestion that is made by way of amendment, that is, that we ought to be adopting in this country codes of conduct such as those recommended by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which do not make it an option for companies to provide the range of information that is necessary to assess their income properly but require them to provide full scale information. Without the information it will not be possible to do the sorting out that is necessary to come to terms with the practices that are involved in industries such as the one that I have been speaking about.

In summary, it seems to me that it is important and it is a good thing that this legislation has been introduced. The new section that is being introduced undoubtedly is in line with informed views about what ought to be done. So what remains is to ask the Government whether the will will be there to ensure that the section is pursued at least to the extent possible within the constraints which undoubtedly will arise when it is tested before the High Court. But certainly the scrutiny arrangements go a long way further than what is in the Act. The Opposition has no quibble with what is actually being done, but we suggest in the form of an amendment that the penalties ought to be strengthened and we suggest that there ought to be a code of conduct for transnational organisations which ensures that the Commissioner of Taxation gets information that currently it appears he is not able to get.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Mr G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the introduction of these amendments which give effect to the new zone allowance arrangements which were announced in the Budget Speech last year but which were not finalised until 15 November last. It is very interesting to note that the Australian Labor Party has not made any substantive comment or offered support on the zone allowance amendments. It is questionable whether the ALP supports this important provision for people living in remote Australia. In so many areas of economic policy the ALP is deficient. In fact, every time the Government starts to do exciting things with the economy to save income tax the ALP leaders resort to putting on a condom and frustrating the efforts.

SPEECH.PARA: The zone allowance decision is only a small component of this package of amendments but it is significant for people in the Northern Territory and in other remote areas of Australia. The amendment to section 79A of the principal Act will enact the three major parts of the Government's decision on zone allowances. First, the basic rebates for zone A and zone B will remain at their present levels of $216 and $36 respectively while the part of the rebate related to dependants will increase from 25 per cent to 50 per cent of the relevant dependants rebates for people in zone A and from 4 per cent to 20 per cent for those in zone B. In addition, a whole new category of people eligible for further assistance, over and above that which is already available, has been created. For a taxpayer living in zone A or B, but at a place in excess of 250 kilometres by the shortest practicable surface route from the centre of a population centre of 2,500 people or more, the basic rebate will be at a special level of $750, instead of the ordinary basic amount of $216 or $36.

Another aspect of the package which I welcome is that the existing test for people to qualify for a zone rebate is to be modified so that a person who resides in a zone area for more than one-half of a calendar year but who, at present, does not satisfy the test in relation to an income year will receive a rebate. The modified test will first apply for the 1981 calendar year and the 1981-82 income year. So, if a person arrived in Darwin in mid-February this year and resided there until mid-December this year he will have had more than six months of the 1982 calendar year in the area and will thus be entitled to a zone rebate for the 1981-82 income year.

One of the recommendations of the Cox report into zone allowances which related to the realignment of zone boundaries was, I am pleased to say, rejected by the Government. The particular recommendation was for towns with a population of over 25,000 in zone A to become zone B and for zone B to be dropped from the zone areas. This decision means that Darwin will continue to be classified in zone A and eligible for the higher benefits. If the recommendation to transfer taxpayers resident in Darwin from zone A to zone B had been adopted it would have meant cash loss of approximately $611 per annum for an average family living in Darwin. I am sure honourable members will appreciate the very real problems this would have produced for family budgets and for industrial peace in the community.

When zone allowances were first introduced in 1945 it was stated that their purpose was to provide some means of income tax relief to taxpayers living in remote parts of the country. The three criteria used to determine remote zones were difficult climatic conditions, isolation, and the higher cost of living in these areas. Isolation is still very much a part of life in the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory has a small, highly dispersed population. We are separated by long distances from the major population centres and economic centres in Australia. Travel from the Territory to other capital cities is costly and the distances involved are so great that people are forced to fly. The current economy class return air fare between Darwin and Canberra, for example, is $671. For a family of four this works out at just under $2,700. In addition, our access to educational, medical, cultural and recreational facilities and services to which persons in non-remote areas are accustomed is limited.

Territorians who wish to attend university or pursue many other areas of tertiary study are forced to go interstate. At the same time the cost of living in the Northern Territory is substantially higher than it is in the non-remote regions of Australia. The cost disadvantage is exacerbated by the impact of transport costs on the wide range of items which have to be imported; the smallness of local markets, which restricts the opportunities for achieving economies of scale; and high local labour costs. There are two broad objectives and justifications for zone allowances. Firstly, they are a compensation for disabilities and disadvantages; secondly, they are an incentive to permanent settlement in remote areas and the attendant development of those areas.

Having dealt with the disadvantages of living in remote areas, I would like to deal briefly with the need for development. From the point of view of defence and national security, there is considerable merit in promoting greater settlement in the northern region of Australia. Increased population in remote areas of Australia would facilitate the protection of the coastline and the preservation of our security against low-level contingencies such as illegal fishing in Australian waters, smuggling and illegal immigration. Of overriding importance, however, is the significant contribution to the rest of the country that the overwhelming wealth of these regions will bring about. The benefits of developing the north of Australia are evident if one considers the following points: The area of Australia which falls into the existing zone A tax boundary contains 85 per cent of Australia's iron ore, 85 per cent of its uranium, 80 per cent of its bauxite, 65 per cent of its copper, 60 per cent of its natural gas and 50 per cent of its silver, lead and zinc, yet we face the problem of attracting people to these areas and getting them to stay there, thus creating a stable population base for future development.

It is in this area that the zone allowances can make a real contribution. The problem with zone allowances, however, is that they do not help people on income benefits, such as pensioners. This is an unfair situation and in many instances causes extreme cases of hardship and poverty. Often the high cost of living in more remote areas forces the elderly upon retirement, to leave and settle down in unfamiliar surroundings with unfamiliar people. The point is that zone allowances will assist only pensioners with additional income from investments. Assistance to the large majority of pensioners and welfare recipients can be achieved only by recognition by the Government that social security benefits and allowances should be substantially and proportionately increased where the recipient is resident in a zone classified for a taxation relief benefit. As one of the pensioners in my electorate put it to me in a letter; if zone allowances for people employed in the Territory are likely to be increased, why cannot something be done for the pensioner? To conclude I re-emphasise the importance of zone allowances. Although not the only consideration in the terms of these amendments, they are a very important measure to thousands of Australians living in remote areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the chance to say a few words on this matter. It is not a matter to which I normally would address my mind but it involves a lot of legal implications in respect of decisions of the High Court of Australia which have been made and which brought about amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act, particularly clause 19, which deals with international agreements and which also refers to the question of arm's length arrangements. I do not want to delay the House but I think the facts which are worthy of comment in my normal sphere of discussing matters in Australia relate to what is deemed to be a free market as against whether there has to be some control of a market.

SPEECH.PARA: I am interested in looking at the position which the Government is attempting to address its mind to, particularly that in respect of what is called ' international agreements'. It is a matter that perhaps would be more appropriately discussed in the Committee of the Whole, but I will not have the chance to do so. I do not wish to disagree with the legislation, except to say that the Government has, I think, drafted proposed section 136AC in a fashion which I do not think will protect it in all circumstances. I want to make the point that proposed new section 136AC which relates to international agreements, states:

(a) non-resident supplied or acquired property under the agreement otherwise than in connection with a business carried on in Australia by the non-resident at or through a permanent establishment of the non-resident in Australia-

Let us say in a nutshell that transactions of a non-resident carrying on business in a permanent position, say in Sydney, for the sale of computer hardware in Hong Kong-I am talking about transfer pricing-would not be covered by that new section. Again there does not seem to be any provision for a resident. The proposed section continues:
(b) a resident carrying on a business outside Australia-

What about a resident carrying on business in Australia? That is another point which I think is important. For example, I think there would be a problem if General Motors-Holden's Ltd, while carrying on business in Australia, decided to export an engine at a price which was below what was deemed to be a fair price. I am not objecting to the present proposals, but I would like to see proposed section 136AC written in this fashion:
. . . an agreement is an international agreement if-
(a) a non-resident supplied or acquired property under the agreement;
(b) a resident carrying on a business outside Australia supplied or acquired property under the agreement, being property supplied or acquired in connection with that business; and
(c) a resident carrying on a business in Australia supplied or acquired property under the agreement, to or from a resident or non-resident carrying on a business outside Australia.

The reason I say that goes back to what I said at the outset. We now find that the High Court decision in what is known as the Comalco case-it was a dreadful decision and one not in accordance with what we would call any normal legal appreciation of the position-stated that because there were four resident directors the carrying on of business was not subject to the protection or control of this particular section of the Act. In fact Comalco was selling bauxite at a false price to a Hong Kong subsidiary to avoid tax in Australia. The High Court, as it was then comprised, particularly with the influence of the Chief Justice, decided to say that even though the company was virtually under the direction of non-residents, because there were resident directors it was exempt. I am pleased to say that Mr Justice Murphy made a very important point that that seemed to be a very superficial arrangement. In other words, we had better look at what the real transactions might be and not just look at them on the basis of what he called absurd formalism.

Again might I address honourable members to what has been happening in a number of other developments in Australia. A company in South Australia called Castalloy Ltd was charged $1,500 a tonne for aluminium produced in Australia. In other words it was really marked up at a high price but the same aluminium was sold to overseas subsidiaries of the aluminium company for $1,200 a tonne. Within Australia we see various operations of transfer pricing, perhaps not so much related to the Income Tax Assessment Act, which can put Australian corporations out of business. In other words that company sold aluminium at a higher price to the Australians than it did to the subsidiary overseas. With the Alusuisse case we saw the remarkable situation of bauxite being marked up about 54 per cent while it was on the high seas.

I am coming to the point that unless we have a strong Act defined in the fashion of what we are about, I think we will run into as many difficulties as the Government is trying to block. For example, at the moment the Repco company while carrying on business outside Australia could be importing back into Australia goods at a price that might not be controlled because it is a resident carrying on business outside Australia. General Motors-Holden's could also be exporting its engines at a price it wants to determine. I do not think this is really covered by the sections I have mentioned. A report brought out recently by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development which mentioned marketing and distribution arrangements makes the point that most of the world trade is intra-firm; that is, within the one corporation. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. When talking about this question of being at arm's length, we come to the point of how the Taxation Commissioner will fix a fair consideration on this matter. How will it be able to do it in accordance with section 136AD, which talks about whether or not arm's length consideration is to be given. What input will it have? It will find it very difficult indeed because it will not have any real indication as to what the market prices should be. One will readily find from this report the problems the world is now facing in dealing with trade. We want to strengthen this section. I ask, firstly, whether it has been properly drafted to cover the matters that I have mentioned and, secondly, will there be the capacity actually to fix the proper consideration, bearing in mind that business is controlled in a very large number of ways?

SPEECH.PARA: I want to illustrate what is happening at present, as it is discussed by this UNCTAD report. For example, most of Japan's trade is carried on within nine major corporations called sogo shoshas. They are the most powerful and diversified of all trading corporations. The report says that whilst competition amongst the sogo shoshas seems to be keen, much of it is illusory because in fundamental matters they work together much more than they compete. The central part of the Japanese conglomerates is the strong financial backing and access to credit, provided not only by their own banks and insurance companies but also by interlinks with the Industrial Bank of Japan. The report goes on to give some indication of how it is expanding its operation. Brazilian exports of footwear, for example, were until recently controlled by the United States but now they are controlled primarily through one of the sogo shoshas and the non-leather footwear from Brazil comes through Mitsubishi.

In other words, we can pick any country in the world now to indicate clearly the control exercised by a number of conglomerates, which will be involved in transfer pricing, the use of tax havens and certainly the use of retail outlets to fix prices in any area in which they want so to do. So, it is a very difficult situation, particularly in this country at present when we have people talking about the real advantages of what they call the effect of the free market being able to indicate clearly the efficient use of financial resources. That is laughable when we see that this report illustrates the great control exercised over the world commodity trade. Even the London Metal Market controls only a very small part of the world metals market. It is a relatively small private concern. So in that context one must ask what facilities the Taxation Commissioner will have to indicate clearly how it will have any access to the major corporate trading conglomerates of the world. I make this point again. The Journal of World Trade Law states:
In fact it can be said that the bulk of the international commodity trade is in the hands of about 50 companies, around which there is a great number of smaller companies . . .

It then goes on to list those companies. I add that there are no such Australian companies, and that is not surprising. There are plenty from the United States and also from France, and certainly from Japan. Again the point comes to how we in Australia can survive this domination of our market due to foreign interests and foreign benefit and gain. No matter what section on the market we look at we now find that the international conglomerates have made a decision that could well be against Australia at any level at all, whether it be at the production level in the first instance or whether it be at the level of getting a share of the market.

Even in regard to the wheat trade we find that the Cargill company, one of the most important international grain merchants, has now expanded into a large number of areas. That is very important indeed. It is the world's largest grain trader. It does business with Russia and has a network covering 36 countries, and it can well establish the price of grain. It became a conglomerate through acquisitions and takeovers. It now deals not only with grain but also with cotton, metals, chemicals, steel et cetera. It has an insurance arm and offers life assurance as well. It also covers marketing as well as speculation. It uses tax havens for all of its international trading outside the United States and Canada, as do most of the other international grain traders. What will happen to the Australian Wheat Board? Does it think it will get a fair price if Cargill decides in some way to affect the market, as well might be the case? That organisation has a subsidiary called Tradex. Tradex, itself, is party owned by Salevia, which is a Swiss foundation whose members are all members of the two families who own Cargill. Between one-third and one-half of Cargill's United States sales are made intrafirm and some of the largest grain shipments from the United States to the Soviet Union were contracted by Tradex; in other words, within the one firm.

This is not a question of thinking now that the world will be fair and reasonable and that matters will be dealt with at arms length. My question is not by way of objection but goes to the capacity of this Government in Australia to ascertain what is really happening when we have this sort of marketing and allocation of resources not by governments in Australia but by international conglomerates that can dictate whether we will have a business or not. I make the point that if the General Motors and Ford companies wanted to abandon their investment in Australia, it could happen tomorrow if they so decided. We would have no control over it. Again we should look at the fact that the conglomerates also control the retail outlets. Retail houses now buy heavily through their own agents and fix prices accordingly.

We have people in Australia and in the Liberal Party trying to indicate that everything will be fair, free and above board simply because we are in Australia and somebody else is somewhere else, at arms length. That is a myth. It ought to be looked at knowing full well that Treasury advice on many occasions is that the only way to go is by what is called the free trade route; that is the most efficient way to go in this country and therefore unless an industry here can stand up for itself it should not be entitled to survive. We should bear in mind that the industry here might well be foreign owned and controlled, as most are. What chance does an industry have if it is up against the conglomerates in the world that are concerned with these matters I raise. So when we talk about this matter let everybody in Australia realise that not only do these people trade within themselves but also they enter into collusive arrangements. They guarantee who might tender in certain circumstances. That has been known and identified. They have arrangements as to who might be the most successful person and they can then make arrangements between themselves to share the wealth.

I now turn to a matter which is of not the least significance. Statements have been made in this House as to how Australia will do well in the diamond trade. I note that this report refers to the Anglo-American Corporation of South Africa. It makes the point that it is a majority owned subsidiary and De Beers-the South African giant-holds 41 per cent. De Beers and AAC together control the whole of the international gold and diamond market. In addition to the directly held subsidiaries, this corporation holds substantial interests through subsidiaries in Great Britain and also in Bermuda. It has 16 enterprises in the United States , Canada, the United Kingdom, Indonesia, Zambia, Australia, Ireland, Portugal et cetera. So we are in the group that internationally could decide how to work out what will be the price of the diamonds we might have. This clearly indicates that not only is this corporation just interested in that. It now has many interests. It has a board of directors that is interlinked. The chairman of the Anglo-American Corporation also presides over the boards of the Anglo-American Trust and De Beers Consolidated Mines. He is also a member of the boards of directors of many other subsidiaries. So, there is no problem about how they will control pricing and dictate to the detriment of the Australian taxpayer from the point of view of getting a product.

What prospect is there of understanding the true position unless there be some kind of government intervention, or opportunity given to know the real price mechanism and thus the Australian tax that a given transaction ought to attract? The board in question has linkages with many expanding complexes. It has interests in the production of minerals and chemicals and, as well, is involved in a number of other activities, commodity trading in particular. It is in the process of acquiring Salomon Bros, one of the largest investment banking enterprises on Wall Street, the stated intention being to create an all-round trading house which services and finances the world's largest producers and consumers of commodities.

Those are the facts that I wanted to put before the House. I appreciate being given a chance to speak on the issue. The activities of those who are in public life are not confined to speaking in the Parliament. We also take part in a number of forums. I have always been mystified by the general acceptance of the fact that in Australia we are very protective: that we are not doing our taxpayers a service. Apparently a large section of the Liberal Party feels that we could well throw our industries open to what is called fair, free and competitive trade. I would not mind that if it were to be done on an equal basis , but that does not accord with what has now been established and published. Organisations such as the United Nations and the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development are endeavouring to establish a code of conduct to deal with these massive corporations.

What are we to do about it? Are we just to sit down, pass this legislation and say: 'We hope everything will happen for the best'? That is not good enough. It is about time we looked at what is happening in the world today and acknowledged that trade is not at all free; it is very much fettered. A continuous endeavour will be made by these conglomerates, in view particularly of currency and exchange rate movements, in relation to which they have access to all these methods of financing and trading, to derive the greatest possible benefits for themselves and to pay the minimum amount of tax. For that reason I would like the Government to consider improving proposed new section 136AC in accordance with the terms I have suggested.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 4, page 4, lines 9 and 10, omit '10 September 1981', substitute '1 July 1979'.
(2) Clause 4, page 4, line 22, omit '10 September 1981', substitute '1 July 1979'.

Clause 4 relates to section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which is intended to ensure that when persons or corporations acquire property and sell the same within 12 months any profit made thereby shall be taxable. As I mentioned in my speech at the second reading stage, this section is being avoided. One simple way of avoiding it is to wait for 12 months and one day before selling a property. That is inherent in the very nature of the section. More seriously, what the Bill addresses itself to is avoidance, which has come to light in the last couple of years, by companies which make takeover raids, acquire shares in substantial numbers and sell them off at a higher price and in a way which means they pay no tax. That is done by putting the shares in a subsidiary company, the almost sole assets of which are those shares, and selling the company rather than the shares. Therefore section 26AAA as it now stand is avoided.

There are three well-known examples of that happening over the last two or three years. In November 1979 the Bell group of companies made a takeover bid for Ansett Transport Industries Ltd. That attempt was eventually abandoned and the group sold off the shares through a subsidiary company and made a tax-free profit of $11m. Similarly, as I mentioned briefly in my speech at the second reading, in March of last year the same Bell group of companies made a takeover raid for Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd, acquired a substantial number of shares in that company, eventually abandoned the takeover attempt and sold off the shares through a subsidiary company-that is, sold that subsidiary company- and made a profit of $16 1/2m which was tax free because the group avoided section 26AAA by selling the company rather than the shares as such. The third well-known example concerns the Bond Corporation, which made a takeover bid for White Industries in August 1980. Like the Bell group, that corporation eventually abandoned the attempt but was able to sell off the shares through a subsidiary company and make a tax-free profit of $32m. Those three examples involve substantial amounts of money. On our calculations the amount of tax avoided in those three cases totalled around $27m. This is a substantial amount of money. Perhaps it is a relatively small amount when compared with the total tax revenue of the Government, but it is an amount which I would have thought this Government would be anxious to obtain.

What is proposed in the legislation now before us is that the operating date for the amendment to this section be 10 September 1981. The reason for taking that date is that it was the day on which the Treasurer (Mr Howard) finally got around to announcing to the world that he would legislate to block this massive loophole in section 26AAA. The policy of the Government in respect of tax avoidance is to operate amendments only from the time at which an announcement was made of the intention to legislate to block off an avoidance scheme. Therefore, the legislation which is before the Committee seeks to block off a tax avoidance scheme which is rampant and concerning which there are several known examples of large amounts of tax revenue being avoided. But the Government does not in any way attempt to obtain that revenue by backdating the legislation to the time of first known use so that $27m can be obtained.

The Opposition cannot see why the Government persists with this stupid approach to anti-tax avoidance legislation. By operating in this way-by continually saying: 'All we will do is to legislate from the time our intention to legislate was announced'-the Government is giving continuous encouragement to tax avoiders to get into new schemes. If one is first in with a scheme one can always get away with it because eventually, when the Government finds out about it, it does not attempt to backdate the legislation. The simply Government says: 'All right, we have now found out about that scheme. From today we will legislate against it '. So the tax avoider is always in front. There is a continual incentive to the tax avoider to generate new schemes knowing that for a while at any rate-perhaps a year or two-he will get away with the scheme before the Government catches up and legislates against it. It is an absurd situation. It is a continuous process of the Australian Taxation Office chasing the tax avoiders but never catching up with them. The situation is getting worse and worse year by year.

We have before us a specific example of how the Government is abandoning revenue of $27m, knowing that the revenue is there to be picked up simply by backdating the legislation to the time of first known use. What we propose by this amendment is that the Income Tax Assessment Act be amended to make the provision apply to the date of first known use. We suggest that it should operate from 1 July 1979 instead of September 1981. The reason we take that date is that it is a few months before the occurrence of the first case which is known to us; that is the case of the Bell group of companies making a takeover bid for Ansett Transport Industries in November 1979. Most of the shares in the Ansett case were probably acquired in the few weeks before the formal takeover bid which occurred, I think, around 25 November 1979. To make certain that we would be picking up most if not all of the shares involved in that transaction we suggest that the operative date be 1 July 1979. Setting the date at the beginning of the financial year would give a neat date from which to make the new legislation operate.

Of course, it is always said by honourable members opposite that we cannot do things like this because it is a terrible thing; it is retrospective legislation . In general, of course, as a matter of principle we share the repudiation that Government members express of retrospective legislation. People may undertake activities which at the time are legal but which are subsequently made illegal by a change of the law. In some cases this seems to be a very undesirable procedure. But in this case we believe that principle has to stand up against the principle of equity for other taxpayers. If we intended to allow tax avoiders to escape retrospective action we must be saying-this Government is saying continuously-that by repudiating retrospectivity in respect of tax avoidance we will continue to allow the tax avoiders always to have a break on the Taxation Office. Therefore, tax avoidance must get worse and worse.

A matter of great principle is involved. We believe in this case the principle which must apply is the one of equity for all Australian taxpayers. We must stop tax avoidance becoming worse and worse, as has occurred over the last few years. I remind the Committee that the number of known tax avoiders was reported by the Commissioner of Taxation in his annual report as being 20 times higher during the last financial year than it was in the last year of the Labor Government. We can see that avoidance is exploding as an enormous problem with massive amounts of revenue being lost. It requires tough action to be taken by government. In those circumstances we believe that application of retrospectivity is justified where blatant tax avoidance is involved. In the case which we are considering now there can be no argument that there was blatant tax avoidance. There was no commercial reason to sell off the shares via these subsidiary companies. Those companies were probably created for the purpose of such transactions-that is, they were shelf companies with no other life or reason for being except for having within them these shares-so that the companies could be sold off to avoid tax by not selling the shares directly. This is absolutely blatant tax avoidance .

In that situation why should we not apply the law retrospectively, back to the time of first known use? Then we would not only collect the revenue in these cases but also we would say to the tax avoiders of Australia: 'We will pursue this principle in future. In all other cases of tax avoidance schemes which come to light requiring action by this Government we, the Government, will make sure that you do not get away with those tax avoidance schemes and will legislate against them back from the time of first known use'. Nothing would be more certain to dissuade tax avoiders in this country from undertaking their nefarious activities than some such action by this Government. It has the chance here today, by supporting this amendment, to make a break with the past and to say to the tax avoidance industry: 'Enough is enough. We will chop you off at the socks from this day on'.

The question to be raised simply is this: If in fact the Government is not prepared to accept the amendments, people involved in corporate takeovers resulting in massive tax free profits will go free. In light of the High Court judgment, particularly in the light of the judgments of Gibbs, Mason and Murphy, the Commissioner of Taxation ought to contest section 26A. The answer from the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to my question was simply this:

So far as this particular case is concerned, let me say to the honourable gentleman that I have no capacity to instruct the Commissioner of Taxation nor, indeed, does any Minister have any capacity to instruct the Commissioner to take particular action against individual taxpayers . . .

I challenge that answer for a variety of reasons. The reason for inaction that is generally touted by Ministers relates to section 16, the secrecy provisions. I regret to say that far too often Ministers hide behind that facade. I think it is an essential rule in Australia that a Minister should be responsible to Parliament for the conduct of his Department. The Treasurer is responsible for the Commissioner's actions or his lack of action. If that be the case, it seems clear to me that the Minister can direct the Department to take a certain course of action and I believe it is the duty of the Department to carry out that action. Surely the Minister must be able to direct the Department to investigate a course of action or even to take a particular course of action. I am not asking that the secrecy provisions be breached and that details of a transaction be revealed but, surely, in the light of the High Court judgment, we have a right to instruct the Commissioner of Taxation to test cases. Five sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act set out the powers to assess and to initiate action. For example, section 166 states:

From the returns, and from any other information in his possession, or from any one or more of these sources, the Commissioner shall make an assessment of the amount of the taxable income of any taxpayer, and of the tax payable thereon.
Section 169 states:
Where under this Act any person is liable to pay tax, the Commissioner may make an assessment of the amount of such tax.
I turn to section 170, which has a retrospective provision. It states:

The Commissioner may, subject to this section, at any time amend any assessment by making such alterations therein or additions thereto as he thinks necessary, notwithstanding that tax may have been paid in respect of the assessment.
Section 222 is the penal provision. It states:
. . . ''taxation prosecution'' means a proceeding by the Crown for the recovery of a pecuniary penalty under this Act.
Section 233 states:
A taxation prosecution may be instituted in the name of the Commissioner by action in the High Court or in the Supreme Court of any State or Territory.

I suggest that under most of these provisions the Commissioner has a discretion; the word used is 'may'. Presumably, if the Commissioner chooses not to assess or to prosecute someone under the Act and someone escapes tax liability, the Commissioner must answer to his Minister. If he answers to the Minister, he answers to the Parliament. Accordingly, the Minister surely ought to be able to direct certain action by his Department and expect it to be carried out. Section 222, which I have already quoted, is interesting. It refers to proceedings instituted by the Crown. This must mean the relevant Minister acting for the Crown. In this case, it is the Treasurer. Encel's book, Cabinet Government in Australia, states:
. . . the minister is responsible to parliament for the conduct of his department, and the actions of civil servants are, by convention, regarded as the acts of ministers.

It seems that far too often in this Parliament Ministers hide behind section 16. Regrettably, it seems to be in part a result of the taxation secrecy provisions and the insularity that breeds, and in part a result of the lack of co- ordination. What bureaucrats in fact do not want or what they are worst at, that is co-ordination. In the light of the judgment to which I have referred-a very important judgment-the Commissioner of Taxation clearly has the power to test a case under either section 26A or section 25 (1). We, as a parliament, create the legislation and surely we are entitled to know whether it is being enforced. In my view it is wrong for the Treasurer to say that he cannot instruct his Commissioner in this matter. We are not asking him to breach the secrecy provisions. What we are asking him to do is to test the High Court judgment in cases of corporate takeovers such as those involving Brierley, Bond and Holmes a Court.

One alternative is that we parliamentarians wait until a legislative committee set up to deal with this Act can ask the Commissioner questions. At the moment we have to rely on his annual report, and I doubt very much whether we will find in it a notation as to whether action has been taken against companies controlled by these people and companies like them. Another alternative is that we wait until next year for the Estimates committees. A matter of $32m is involved in the Bond takeover and $16.5m in the dealings of the Holmes a Court Bell group. That is the tip of the iceberg. If we add up all the amounts, we find that millions upon millions of dollars turn on the High Court judgment. It is not a question of whether the amendments are accepted. My guess is that they will not be accepted. But the one thing the Government has a responsibility to ensure is that the Commissioner tests that judgment and act against the people who have tried to avoid their taxation obligations under section 26AAA or, in this case, section 26A.

Let me make another observation. Had we not tightened up the Slutzkin loophole, in my view we would have had a further obligation to instruct the Commissioner to contest such schemes in the High Court. We ought to have done that. We ought not have waited for so long. I intend to pursue this matter right through the year to ensure that ultimately these people are taken to book either under the amended legislation or under section 26 (a) or section 25 (1).

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 23, page 38, lines 16-18, omit 'calculated, in respect of the period commencing on the last day allowed for furnishing the return of income for the year of income and ending on the day on which the assessment is made, at the rate of 10 per cent per annum of', substitute 'equal to'.

Clause 23 deals with penalties for breach of proposed new Division 13 relating to transfer pricing activities or for breach of a double taxation agreement in the same respect; that is, when it applies to transfer pricing. The clause before us provides for a penalty of 10 per cent per annum of the tax sought to be avoided. This seems to the Opposition to be an extremely low penalty. I make my point by comparing that 10 per cent penalty with other penalties applying under the Income Tax Assessment Act. Of course, there are penalties for persons who make false returns, who omit or understate their incomes or who in other ways attempt to avoid or evade tax.

These penalties vary in their impact, but in most cases they provide for a much more severe penalty than that envisaged under this Bill for transfer pricing- type tax avoidance. For instance, section 226 (1) provides a penalty of additional tax equal to the tax assessable-that is, a penalty of 100 per cent, not 10 per cent-for any taxpayer who fails to furnish any return or information required by the Act or the Commissioner of Taxation. Section 226 (2) provides a penalty of double the tax sought to be avoided for any person omitting assessable income or claiming a rebate or deduction in excess of expenditure actually incurred. A penalty of similar magnitude is provided under section 227 and section 230 for taxpayers who make false returns or understate their incomes . These penalties are double the tax sought to be avoided, compared with the 10 per cent penalty applying in clause 23 of the Bill now before us.

Section 226 (2A) also provides for a 200 per cent penalty for persons caught evading tax by the new general anti-avoidance section 177 which was enacted last year. This, of course, is an extremely relevant comparison because in framing this legislation for proposed new Division 13 regard was paid to Part IVA. I think an attempt was made to interrelate the two provisions, but the penalty side is staggeringly different. Under Part IVA the general anti-avoidance provision a 200 per cent penalty is imposed. Under new proposed Division 13 a miserable 10 per cent penalty will apply. Section 229 provides for four years imprisonment for taxpayers who knowingly make false declarations under the Act. Obviously this is a rather more drastic penalty than a penalty of 10 per cent of the tax sought to be avoided.

The penalty contained in proposed new Division 13 is almost insignificant. A penalty of 10 per cent is ludicrously low. It is hard to see how it could act as any deterrent at all to persons or companies contemplating the risks of undertaking such tax avoidance. When the amounts involved were substantial, for example, the amount of tax avoided could be re-invested easily by the taxpayer at an interest rate of, say, 20 per cent-it would not be hard to get that rate of interest these days on large amounts of money. When or if the person or company was brought to task by the operation of proposed new Division 13 and was required to repay the tax avoided, plus 10 per cent per annum penalty tax, the taxpayer or the company concerned would still be well ahead on the arrangement. This is a situation in which the penalty will not be big enough to dissuade people from undertaking that kind of activity. A person could make more money by lending the money he succeeded in withholding from the Commissioner of Taxation under these arrangements than he is likely to pay in a penalty if, in fact, he is eventually caught up with.

We regard this as a thoroughly unsatisfactory provision all round. Indeed, in some cases the penalty may not even be as high as 10 per cent. The penalty applies only for the period between the due date for providing an income tax return and the day on which the assessment is due. Thus if for example returns were due on 31 August and an amended assessment was finally made at the end of April, the penalty would apply only for nine months at an annual rate of 10 per cent, which in this case would be effectively a flat rate of 7.5 per cent. In many cases the penalty may not even be 10 per cent but may be something less than that.

Therefore, the penalty contained in clause 23 is really no penalty at all. It is really little more than levying interest at the rate of 10 per cent per annum on the amount of tax avoided, which the tax avoider retains the use of until he is caught by the Taxation Office. As such, it is similar to section 207 of the principal Act, which applies a penalty only for late payment of tax. It levies a 10 per cent rate of interest on outstanding tax due. However, this section dates such interest to the time when the tax return is due rather than to the date when tax becomes payable, as is the case with section 207. This, of course, is an area in which the misdemeanour is relatively minor. It is late payment of tax , not an attempt to avoid taxation and to defraud the Commissioner of Taxation in some way.

It seems to the Opposition that the 10 per cent penalty is ludicrously low and is in need of substantial change. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his second reading speech gave no reason for the imposition of such a low penalty. In fact, the Treasurer seemed to say: 'What a great idea this penalty is because it will be so effective'. In his second reading speech he said:

An important feature of the new provisions is that, subject to powers of remission, a statutory penalty will be imposed, equal to 10 per cent per annum of the tax becoming payable by virtue of the revised provisions. Without that, taxpayers who engage in profit shifting to reduce their Australian tax liabilities, would have the odds to nothing when they engaged in such arrangements.

I suggest the reality is that with the low 10 per cent penalty which is provided the taxpayers engaged in these sorts of operations will still have the odds to almost nothing. There will still be a real financial incentive for them to undertake tax avoidance activity of a transfer pricing nature. If they are caught the penalty will not be one which will make the activity unprofitable. They will still be in front because, as I said, they will have been able to use that money in a way which would get them a return well above the 10 per cent penalty. The Opposition thinks that this clause is quite deficient in providing only a 10 per cent penalty. The Treasurer has given no reason for picking such a low figure. He seems to the Opposition to have quite unwisely stated the belief that this will be a very effective penalty when in fact there is no reason to believe that will be so. Indeed, there is great reason to believe the opposite- that this will be a very ineffective penalty. That is why I have moved these amendments to clause 23 to increase the penalty from 10 per cent to 200 per cent .

One wonders, even at this stage whether the Government might have another look at the question of penalties to see whether it is possible to accept the amendments that have been suggested by the honourable member for Gellibrand, which simply try to introduce some consistency into the legislation. I think a number of members have made the point that the Act is now extremely complex and that the tendency is to make it more and more complex. One would have thought that one of the things that companies which may not be particularly enthusiastic about this legislation would at least like is general consistency. Even though they would not particularly like to have to face the sorts of penalties which are covered in Part IVA and which we are suggesting ought to be represented in this clause, at least it would suggest some level of consistency. So we are not dealing in this aspect of legislation with small business but we are really dealing with the very largest corporations which are involved in considerable risk-taking and which are investing in this country and in other countries in our regions tens or perhaps hundreds of millions of dollars in particular projects. As they are dealing with very large amounts of money indeed they have considerable power with governments. On the one hand the Government ought to be suggesting that where people are not prepared to conform to what we regard as good practice in terms of Australian interests, where they are attempting to get around our taxation laws-avoid our taxation laws-they ought to recognise and they ought to know that a very severe risk is involved. All these amendments try to do is to suggest those things and to impose a penalty which is commensurate with penalties in the other sections of the Act and commensurate with the scale of the kinds of activities that are involved when transfer pricing is the issue.
