TALK.START.PARA: —The Loan Bill 1982 is a conventional subterfuge to allow the Commonwealth to avoid obtaining approval for its borrowing through the Australian Loan Council. The financial agreement between the Commonwealth and the States covers all borrowing by the Commonwealth and the States except Commonwealth borrowing for defence. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) habitually uses this exemption each year to obtain parliamentary authorisation for government borrowing without first going to the Loan Council. The Loan Bill authorises the Commonwealth to borrow and expend money for defence purposes even though the borrowing approval is sought principally because of increases in other spending and a shortfall in expected taxation receipts. However, Treasurers of both parties have used this convoluted arrangement for many years so there is no point in making a big issue of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Loan Bill has been brought in very late in the financial year; it is normally introduced at Budget time to allow for the borrowing of funds required to cover part of any deficit. During 1981-82 expenditure increased significantly above the level appropriated as a result of the Budget and tax receipts have been below expectations. Therefore borrowing approval has been sought late in the financial year to make up part of the shortfall.

I use the opportunity of speaking on this Bill to make some more general observations, not only on the issue of government borrowings but also on the general fiscal and economic policy that has been pursued by the Government. In passing I refer to the need, as I understand it, for debate not only within the party room of the Government but also within other parties and indeed within the community about an alternative economic policy. Of course there has clearly been a difference between the Government's position and that of the Opposition with respect to fiscal policy. We argue at this point, as we have argued during the life of this Government, that a more stimulating fiscal policy is necessary and is what Australia needs at present. We believe that the preoccupation with a deficit of successive governments under the leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is a pre-occupation which has not a great deal of meaning in economic terms. For example, I think it has argued for a number of years by the Prime Minister that there is a relationship between the size of the deficit and the level of inflation. If one looks at what has happened under the Government we see that no necessary relationship exists between the two; that is, that irrespective of the scale of deficit, relatively high inflation has continued. This year, in which the Government set out to achieve a balanced domestic budget -although, of course, it will not achieve that-we have significantly high inflation and certainly, I am sure, much higher than the Government desires.

But more seriously the Government is now confronted with a situation in which the economy is deeply recessed. We are talking about the situation in which many of the signs indicate the depth of the current recession which, quite rightly I think, ought to be understood as not simply a recession within this country but a recession in an international context. One could argue that in the circumstances-I think the Opposition has consistently argued this-we ought to be using a fiscal and monetary policy in a counter-cyclical way; that is, in the current circumstances we ought to be doing what the Japanese Government is seeking to do. At a time when Japan is finding it difficult to sell its products overseas because international trade is depressed the Government is seeking to boost its domestic expenditure, to get domestic construction programs underway and generally to ensure that at least domestically enough activity is generated in the economy to provide higher levels of employment.

I go on to refer briefly to some of the differences that exist particularly within the Liberal Party, because that is where I understand some debate has taken place. In my view it is rather sad that it has taken a leadership challenge by a challenger without any specific ideas and proposals finally to persuade the Liberal Party that at least there may be serious questions to be asked about the Government's economic policy. Of course, one cannot believe that there will be any significant changes in the thrust of Government policy as a result of these discussions. If one relies on Press reports the debate seems to be largely between those who would pursue even more draconian and restrictive policies and those who want more of the same, perhaps spiced with a little more humanity in the form of tax cuts.

However, all the evidence would suggest to me that a much more dramatic reappraisal is necessary in terms of the Government's economic policy and perhaps a fundamental change of direction. Cosmetic changes will not be enough to free us from the malaise which is a legacy of past mistakes, compounded by a very difficult international economic situation. It is easy to point to the evidence of the Government's failure. After all, we were promised a great deal; lower inflation, lower interest rates, jobs for all who wanted to work, a revival of Australia's key industries, higher growth rates and ever expanding export markets for our resource wealth. Clearly the indicators are not good on any of these points and it is not difficult for the Opposition, given the litany of broken promises, which is the record of this Government, to raise these matters as debating points and to establish that the economy and indeed society are facing a number of serious and intractable problems.

From the Government's record, which in my view is on the whole a pretty sorry record, it would seem to me that a number of lessons should be learnt if we are to move to what is needed, that is, a new economic policy. Firstly, one can argue, on the basis of experience in this country and to some extent with reference to overseas developments, that monetarism is effectively dead as the basis of successful economic policy. For nearly seven years now we have had policies with restrictions on the money supplied as their essential tenet. The reality is that this experiment has failed in Australia, just as it has failed in Britain and as it is in the process of failing in the United States. Each of these countries faces not only higher levels of inflation but also extremely cruel levels of unemployment. It would seem to me that any development of a new or alternative economic policy in Australia would need to approach the question of the money supply much more flexibly, recognising that unemployment is as serious a scourge on society as inflation.

The second lesson that should have been learnt during the last few years is that what is required in Australia or in any economy is some balance between the needs of different sectors of the economy as well as between the domestic and export sectors. This is fairly relevant to the Bill before us and to the question of Loan Council borrowings. Less than two years ago the Government was promising a massive boom in resource industries. The sky was the limit. Prospects, listed with zillions of dollars, were going to lift the Australian economy to unprecedented levels. Now, in the context of the current international recession, many of the projects listed have been cancelled and the boom has largely dissipated, if it was ever really there. The point that I wish to stress is that a more internationally integrated economy, so strongly promoted by this Government, has risks associated with it as well as opportunities. In a period of recession, with the bottom falling out of international markets, too great a bias in the economy towards exports can lead to serious problems for the domestic economy made dependent on exports for income. A more integrated Australian economy would be, in my view, a much more dependent economy and one which will fluctuate much more seriously according to international circumstances.

In Australia in the past few years particular store has been placed not so much on exports as a whole but on the development of mineral processing industries, capital and energy intensive in character and export orientated, which, it has been argued, will do much to lift growth rates and to produce higher levels of national income and which will succeed within a world which is hungry for energy and hungry for Australian minerals. Whilst in the longer term it may well be true that Australia has a great asset in terms of its mineral and energy resources, the reality is that inherently these resource industries have been cyclical in nature. For example, the aluminium industry-to which I referred before the suspension of the sitting in the context of another debate-has risen and fallen pretty much in line with international booms and recessions. That industry has been expanded very largely for export purposes. It was expanded on the basis of predicted levels of growth which would occur in the period between 1980 and 1985. We have dramatically increased capacity both in alumina refining and in smelting within this country and very large amounts of capital have been invested in both the private and public sectors. The success of that whole venture has depended on certain projections about growth rates in the demand for aluminium. Of course the reality has been that those growth rates simply have not occurred. The expected 4 per cent growth rate between 1980 and 1985 just has not materialised. In fact, we have had negative growth rates and now there are serious doubts as to whether the metal can be sold. In turn, that is resulting in agreements being made which perhaps raise some of the problems in regard to transfer pricing that were referred to in an earlier debate; that is that companies, rather than selling their metal on any sort of market, are entering into agreements. Such an agreement in the case of CRA Ltd involved the purchase of a Japanese company so that it could achieve entry into the Japanese market and secure long term prospects for selling its metal.

This reshaping of the economy around the so-called resource industries has occurred in a climate of certain expectations which quite clearly have not materialised, at least in the short term, in the way that either the Government or the corporate planners associated with these developments really expected. We put a lot of eggs in that particular basket. A lot of resources have been devoted in the case I mentioned. In the public sector, resources have been devoted to providing electricity very rapidly through accelerated electricity programs in various States. That, in itself, has created all sorts of problems. One can think back to the Premiers Conference in 1978. The Federal Government encouraged the States-it almost pleaded with them-to borrow much larger amounts of money under the special infrastructure loan programs so that they could get these power programs under way. The States responded to the offer of a more or less open cheque for loan funds from the Commonwealth and they got started on projects for a dramatic expansion of electricity generation, very largely for the aluminium and other energy intensive industries. Now we are in a situation where the markets are not materialising. Smelters are being slowed down and power stations have remained under construction. The whole capital priorities of the country were geared towards a program which was really based on expectations that perhaps were unreal right from the start. The problem to which I am referring is a product of believing that we can somehow move from one kind of economy and its particular structure to another in a very short time.

I think largely the initiative for this development did not come from the Government; it came from these large corporations that saw an opportunity to get a handle on Australian resources and to develop profitable businesses in relation to them. But-this brings me to the third major point that I want to make-the Government has inherent within it this very strong commitment to so- called private enterprise and to development occurring perhaps not in the interests of the Australian people as a whole but in the interests of the private sector on the understanding that somehow, if we encourage the private sector to do what it will, the benefits will filter down or will flow through to the Australian people. The experience of the last few years ought to be seen as a very salutary experience and, in terms of formulating an effective economic policy in the future, we ought to place much greater emphasis on the need for orderly and planned development of our human and physical resources as opposed to reliance on what I call the so-called market forces. It is at this point indeed that one can see most clearly the contradictions which are inherent in conservative economic philosophy and policy. There is no doubt that all sections of the Liberal Party eschew planning. We are told that this is not a matter in which governments should intervene in such a way as would restrict the freedom of choice of private enterprise.

The argument ignores, of course, the fact that the commanding heights of the so -called private sector are themselves heavily into corporate planning and the minimisation of risk or, effectively, the elimination of free markets. If and when investments reach the scale of tens and even hundreds of millions of dollars, corporations simply cannot afford to tolerate free competition which would place them too much at risk. The name of the game is risk minimisation in planning. As the choice is increasingly one between government planning and corporate planning, or between government planning and so-called free enterprise , it is not really a choice between government planning and free and open competition.

To examine any one of the major industries in this country is but to make that point crystal clear. If we consider such basic, nationally important industries as those which produce steel, chemicals or paper products, aluminium or motor vehicles we see that they do not represent a private enterprise free market situation. A small number of very powerful firms between them control the total market in Australia. In some cases, a single firm can meet the total demand for its product in Australia. For example, in my electorate Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd has a plant which would, as far as many classes of paper and paper board are concerned, produce the total output of the country. Any supposed competition with APM in the areas in which it specialised would be quite illusory; it would not be significant.

In the past few years, under this so-called free enterprise Government, we have seen changes that are inherent in allowing the corporate sector unfettered power to plan. It would appear that the corporate sector, with all the knowledge that is at its disposal, has failed to anticipate the depth of the current recession, even in cyclical industries such as the aluminium industry. The result has been that it has encouraged too rapid development, which is likely to mean idle or under-utilised capital in both the public and the private sectors. The combination of tight monetary policies and the immense demand on capital has meant a squeeze on capital spending across the board, so that the standard of living and access to services by people has been restricted while a few major projects have gone ahead, though even they may not be economic for a few years.

To cite an obvious example, under this Government interest rates have increased by some 4 per cent in two years and housing interest rates have gone through the roof. This means that, as a result of government policy, the funds available for housing, as one form of social purpose, have been tightly restricted in order to make money available for capital works in other areas of the economy. Thus corporate planners have determined not only private sector priorities but also public sector priorities, with what can only be regarded as disastrous results. Careful planning by government could have allowed development in capital energy- intensive industries, without distorting public sector priorities or producing, as a consequence, very high interest rates.

I turn briefly to the issue of employment. An alternative economic policy must seek to redefine objectives. Since 1975 there has been a central and overriding preoccupation with inflation. The promise that inflation would be kept to manageable levels has not been fulfilled. Yet, alongside very high levels of inflation, we have maintained a very large and still growing pool of unemployment. For 30 years prior to 1975 full employment had been the fundamental objective of economic policy. The suffering imposed on the unemployed in our society is extreme and unacceptable. We cannot hope to continue on the present course without fundamentally dividing the nation and doing extreme damage to tens of thousands of lives. Therefore, in my view we need to restore the historical emphasis on full employment and to regard the past few years as an aberration.

I argue that in the short term this involves reorienting public sector expenditure to ensure that it does not, in fact, encourage further unemployment. More positively, the contribution to employment ought to be an important criterion for public sector expenditure. In other words, I believe that the emphasis on employment ought not to be a matter which is of concern to only one ministry called, say, the ministry of employment, but rather, should enjoy a fundamental priority which will cut across all public sector spending. Therefore , one ought to be budgeting for full employment and ensuring that all programs are examined in terms of their implications for employment. The present Government, while cutting back on capital works in the area of social infrastructure, has been prepared to encourage capital works in areas which suit the corporate planning sector. It has not sought to direct capital spending to those areas of the economy which will provide employment and also assist in the creation of a more efficient economy overall.

In short, we need to work towards an alternative model of economic development which recognises the key role of the public sector in determining overall investment priorities. This was, after all, the thrust of the policies pursued by Chifley in the post-war reconstruction period. The Government sought to spell out its priorities for economic and social development on the basis of what was believed to be a consensus in the community as to what those priorities were. Clearly, in the present situation people are seeking social and economic security which implies both full employment and reduced inflation.

I am not suggesting for a moment that a government ought to be seeking to restore full employment without at the same time seeking to deal with problems of inflation. I accept, as a number of my colleagues have argued, that a prices and incomes policy is quite crucial with respect to inflation. Indeed, one wonders about a government that has placed so much emphasis on fighting inflation-with fighting inflation first as its highest priority-yet has failed to develop a coherent wages policy and, indeed, is now in a position in which it is unable significantly to influence wages policy in this country. That is to take one side of an incomes and prices policy and to overlook for a moment the fact that this is the Government that not only emasculated the Prices Justification Tribunal but finally, last year, decided as a part of the razor gang exercise to eliminate it altogether.

If the Government was concerned with achieving some kind of fairness in terms of the distribution of shares within this community, with getting some kind of agreement about social priorities, if it was convinced that a large section of the community believed that inflation had to be fought with all the weapons that could be mustered one would have thought that it not only would have retained something like the Prices Justification Tribunal, but would have sought to beef it up. But, of course, this Government is not a government that is about fairness, not a government that is about trying to develop the economy in the interests of all Australians, if I may use that hackneyed phrase. What this Government has been about is essentially restructuring the Australian economy to suit the interests of those people who are prepared to put most money into the party coffers and who are prepared to provide the most muscle in terms of defending the Government and keeping it in office. The Government has essentially been a government for the corporate sector in a way which is quite divorced from social priorities and social realities.

I would argue that if we were concerned, which this Government clearly is not, about achieving security for people we would require more and not less public intervention. We would require planning and not pseudo-market forces. We would not talk about market forces when we really mean allowing very large corporations to have a free hand without our putting any restrictions on them, regulating their activities or whatever. We would require priorities for public sector spending which emphasise full employment and which set the appropriate climate for the private sector.

This Government, under Mr Fraser, in my view is the first government in the post-war period-one can exclude other Liberal governments in the post-war period -to have seen the interests of the public sector and the private sector as antithetical. The Government believes that there can be a healthy private sector only if it destroys, emasculates or attacks the public sector. In many respects this Government is at war with society. It seeks to confront, browbeat and bully . Meanwhile its ideology is in tatters because it is the victim of its own propaganda. All the indicators-inflation, unemployment, interest rates and growth rates-are there to prove the Government's failure. However, the most tragic aspect is not the statistics. It is the people who suffer when governments are not only insensitive but also, more seriously, wrong. This Government, in terms of the thrust of its economic policy, has been both insensitive and wrong. It is the latter aspect which I think is the most serious . That is why there ought to be genuine debate in the Parliament about future directions of economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this legislation the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) is drawing the curtain on a fundamental aspect of the funding of government schools in this country. This will be the last time that this Government maintains the value of the grants it promised to the States in terms of supporting the costs in government schools. It has been the practice for some time-ever since the Schools Commission programs were commenced-to decide on the level of grants and to supplement them in the following year to take account of cost increases which, in fact, reduce the value of those grants for the earlier year. The legislation before us tonight is designed to supplement the grants for 1981 to take account of cost increases which occurred during that year. Most, if not all, of those cost increases were the result of wage and salary increases. Those costs could not have been avoided by State governments and State systems. The levels of salaries and wages are set almost universally by special tribunals or the normal arbitral processes and, therefore, the State systems have no way of avoiding the consequences of wage and salary increases. Therefore, it has been the practice until now that the State governments have been compensated for the increases that occur in any year. SPEECH.PARA: What we are really debating tonight is the end-the abandonment-of a very important procedure in relation to the funding of schools which did guarantee that State governments received the purchasing power of the grants which were promised to them by the Commonwealth at the time those grants were announced. The Government has said that it is in the interest of improving the administrative efficiency of the procedure to make this change. It says that it is cumbersome and awkward to have to adjust the level of the grants in Parliament once the cost increases are known, after the event. It says that involves more legislation, more time of the House and so forth, so it has designed this streamlined mechanism whereby it can build in what it reckons is an amount adequate to cover forthcoming cost increases. But what we now know, as a result of the defects which have been exposed in this system, is that in fact what this change really means is that there will be an additional reduction in the amount of funds available, particularly to government schools, but also in a roundabout way to non-government schools. That is the serious problem which is being confronted by State government schools throughout Australia. It is occurring at a time when State governments are already experiencing problems in relation to the funding of their schools. I will quote from the document which we are also debating tonight, the Schools Commission Recommendations for 1983. Page 1 states:

All State Governments are experiencing difficulties in providing the recurrent resources required to maintain standards in and services to government schools. Between the 1980/81 and 1981/82 financial years, all States at least maintained the real value of their own recurrent expenditure on government schools. The Australia-wide average real increase was approximately 3.0 per cent. Despite, this, and a slight decline in government school enrolments between 1980 and 1981 . . . there has been a slippage in student-teacher ratios in some States and reductions in the provisions for ancilliary and specialist staff.

What this means is that not only are the funds made available from the Commonwealth slipping back but also State governments are finding it increasingly difficult to maintain from their own resources the level of funding necessary to maintain standards within their schools. That is why it makes it doubly important that the Government abandon this particular process, and return to the procedures for cost supplementation to ensure that this does not become another gradual encroachment on or another gradual reduction in the resources available to government schools. I quote another paragraph from the Schools Commission report. Paragraph 1.3 states:

For those State systems, with static or declining enrolments, there appear to be relatively few short-termed savings if standards are to be maintained. The major enrolment downturns that will occur by the middle of the 1980's, particularly at the secondary level, may enable some resources to be freed for redeployment if governments decide simply to maintain present standards. However , the dislocatory effects and diseconomies of enrolment decline should not be underestimated. The evidence before the Commission is that present enrolment declines which are mainly at the primary level do not produce swift or automatic savings and may indeed, in the absence of actual school closures, produce higher costs associated with the need to maintain uneconomic class sizes and to phase in the application of staffing formulae which dictate redeployment. They also result in higher per student maintenance costs and more expensive support services. The diseconomies associated with maintaining the standard of educational services to rural areas in the face of a shrinking rural population are long-standing examples of this problem. Diseconomies in large areas of urban schooling-for example, Sydney's eastern suburbs-are a more recent phenomenon.

What that paragraph does is to blow apart the Government's argument in support of reductions of funds for government systems. What the Minister has been telling us for more than a year is that the declining enrolments in the government systems, which have been rather marginal and maybe illusory, are a justification for reducing the level of funding for government systems. Now, in fact, the Government is being told by the Schools Commission that the Schools Commission can foresee no savings and, indeed, it suspects that there will be actual increases in costs as a result of enrolment declines because of the patchy, lumpy way in which those enrolment declines have occurred. They do not occur in a way which allows schools simply to reduce all school costs by a standard percentage. They occur in a way which may prevent any economies and, indeed, in some circumstances, may force higher per pupil costs on State government systems. That is a very serious revelation on the part of the Schools Commission, because, as I say, it really gives the lie to what the Government's chief argument has been in terms of reductions in the real level of resources to government schools which have occurred in recent times.

According to page 30 of the report, in the years from 1976 until 1983-that is, if the Schools Commission's recommendations for 1983 are adopted-there will have been a 10 per cent reduction in real terms in funds for government schools at a time when, if these recommendations are accepted, there will have been an increase of nearly 78 per cent in real terms in funds available for non- government schools. That represents an extraordinarily serious shift, in terms of resources, away from the government system towards the non-government system. The Government has really failed to address the very serious consequences of that policy. It has failed to heed the advice of the Commission on numerous occasions in relation to the locked-in nature of the transfers from government to non-government schools which are inherent in this Government's policies.

In the first instance, subsidies for non-government schools are based on a percentage of standard government school costs; that is, once the standard government school cost has been determined, a certain percentage is applied and a dollar figure ascertained and becomes the level of per capita dollar subsidy for students in the different levels in non-government schools. As the costs have been increasing in government schools, obviously the subsidies to non- government schools have also been increasing as a result of the calculation of the subsidies on that basis. Of course, this has been exacerbated by the slight but nevertheless real decline in government school enrolments which has forced up, as the Schools Commission reveals in its report, the cost in government schools.

There we have two factors which have been pushing up the subsidies to non- government schools. In adition to those increases, the Government has been adjusting the percentage level of the subsidy. Briefly, what I am saying is that the Government's policy has within it locked-in transfers from the government to the non-government system unless the Government has been prepared to maintain a growing level of funding for schools as a whole. But the Government has not done that; there has been an automatic accelerator in the overall funds going to non- government systems. In circumstances where the overall budget for schools has not been increasing, the consequence has been a quite savage decline, of the order of 10 per cent in real terms, in the amount of funds going to the government system. What this has meant in terms of the shares of Commonwealth funds going to schools is that, whereas in the last Labor Budget 64 per cent of Federal funds went to government schools, this year the proportion has fallen to 49 per cent. Even if the Schools Commission's recommendations for 1983 are adopted, it will fall a further percentage point to 48 per cent next year. That is a very substantial decline in the share of funds going from the Commonwealth to Government schools in which-this is still the case, and I suspect it has always been the case-75 per cent of this country's school age children are enrolled. So the Government's policies have resulted in a very substantial neglect in relation to government schools at a time, as has been revealed by the Schools Commission, when State governments themselves are finding it increasingly difficult to find the necessary funds from their own resources to make up the difference.

The Government always said, or has been saying in recent times, that its justification for reducing funds to government schools has been because of the achievement of the so-called Karmel targets. It is true that the targets recommended by the Karmel report in 1973 have been reached. Therefore, the Fraser Government appears to believe that its obligation to be concerned about education resources for government schools has now ended. We have to remember and be clear in our minds that the Karmel targets were specifically designed towards 'overcoming within a reasonable period the worst schooling deficiences'. There was not a statement about the desirable level of resources which would guarantee Australian children an adequate educational opportunity. The achievement of the Karmel targets by government schools has occurred in an era of contracting Commonwealth support only because the State governments have been able to find within their own resources the ability to provide extra resources to their own schools. The reason for that has been the very generous funding arrangements which the Whitlam Government instituted in relation to general tax reimbursements for the states. With the disappearance of the Whitlam guarantee the Fraser Government has now been able to exert a sort of fiscal pressure on State governments to ensure that they no longer have the ability to provide the resources necessary to maintain the level of resources within their schools, and that has the exacerbating effect of reducing Commonwealth funding in this area as well.

Of course, it is true that conditions in government schools have improved greatly since the disastrous conditions which prevailed prior to the election of the Labor Government in 1972. The efforts that have been made by the Commonwealth, both in terms of direct grants and in terms of providing additional general funds for the States, have been very important in overcoming those problems. But that is not to say that the improvements have been sufficient or that we can rest on the achievements that have been made to date. We have to make certain that there is a reassessment of the necessary resource levels in government schools to ensure that there is adequate educational opportunity, indeed an equal opportunity, for all Australian children.

It is the failure of this Government to accept the sorts of resource standards which the Schools Commission has been urging on it which has really led us to the problem we are now in. Unless the Commonwealth government is prepared to accept a level of resources necessary for the maintenance and, indeed, achievement of educational opportunity within Australia we will simply have a continuation of the process which has been occurring in recent years of a continuing drift of Commonwealth funds in particular away from the government school system. Therefore 75 per cent of the kids enrolled in schools in this country will be disadvantaged to that extent.

That is the measure of this Government's lack of concern for standards, particularly within government schools, and the Government stands condemned on that basis.

I emphasise that the Commission is the Government's principal source of independent advice on the needs of schools.

During the debate the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child) reflected upon the Schools Commission. She indicated that in her view it was no longer independent and that the charter had been changed. I want to emphasise that the Commission works under the same charter as it operated under when it was first established. Reference was also made to the fact that this Government issues financial guidelines to the Commission. I want to say that we follow in the footsteps of the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden), who, when he was Treasurer of this country in 1975, provided the first financial guidelines to the Commission.

However, it is the Government which has final responsibility for policy. The Commission makes the recommendations but it is the Government which has the final responsibility for policy on the development and funding of programs of assistance for schools. Accordingly, the Government reserves the right to initiate policies and lay down financial guidelines in the context of its overall priorities and the need for tight budgetary controls.

The Government reiterates that the central objective of its schools funding policies is the provision of the highest standard of schooling for all students, whether enrolled in government or non-government schools. State governments provide the bulk of total expenditure on government schools-some 89 per cent- whereas the States provide about only 34 per cent of total public funds for non- government schools. The Commonwealth's role in these circumstances is to provide topping-up funds to government schools which are equivalent to about 11 per cent of total public expenditure on government schools. The remaining 89 per cent is obtained from Commonwealth revenue sharing grants and Loan Council allocations to the States which, along with funds from State sources, are spent by the States according to their priorities, not according to our priorities. In that context I draw attention to the fact that the honourable member for Fremantle ( Mr Dawkins), in responding on behalf of the Opposition, made reference to what he described as a fact-that the Commonwealth had applied financial pressure to the States. Let me remind him and the House that Commonwealth general purpose revenue funds to the States have generally been maintained in real terms in recent years.

I want to emphasise a point that has already been made by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume), that is, that as a result of Commonwealth and State efforts-I emphasise, as a result of Commonwealth and State efforts-the Schools Commission has reported that recurrent expenditures per student in Government school systems increased in real terms by about 20 per cent between 1975-76 and 1979-80. I want to say that again because I want it to be placed not only solidly in the record but also solidly in the minds of the Opposition. During the period that this Government has been in office in the Commonwealth recurrent expenditure per student in government school systems has increased in real terms by almost 20 per cent. That is a massive increase. Despite these achievements and the continuing decline in government school enrolments, the Commonwealth Government has maintained the real level of general recurrent funding for government schools in recent years. Because of the enrolment decline in Government schools since 1978, Commonwealth general recurrent funds on a per student basis have increased in real terms. On the other hand the Commission states in its report that the great majority of non-government schools have on average recurrent expenditure levels well below the standard cost of educating a student in a government school. The report also shows that overall pupil-teacher ratios in government schools are more favourable than those in non-government shools.

SPEECH.PARA: I deal first in regard to this matter with the question of the end of cost supplementation. I indicated earlier in the debate on schools that it had been the practice of the Labor Government and of Liberal governments prior to this Government to ensure that the value of the promised grants to universities and colleges would be restored by a retrospective adjustment after cost increases could be calculated. Now we see in one of the Bills before us tonight the end of cost supplementation. The year 1981 will be the last year for which cost supplementation exists. For 1982 and beyond we will have this theoretical anticipatory adjustment to funds which is supposed to take into account the cost increases which are mainly as a result of the wages and salaries costs incurred by universities and colleges. Earlier this year the Academic Salaries Tribunal recommended what might be described as modest increases for academics in universities and colleges throughout Australia. The 1982 full cost of the implementation of those increased salaries will be $75m. So, if the Government does not provide that $75m, or if it has not been adequately provided for in the prospective allowance, that will cost something like 300 jobs in universities and colleges.

The Minister has said nothing about this except that he will review the consequences of the AST decision and perhaps make some adjustment accordingly. There is no guarantee that the real value of the grants-their purchasing power- such as they are, promised to universities and colleges in 1982 will be maintained. All that this legislation does is to adjust retrospectively the consequences of that decision as they affected 1981 in particular. Nothing has been said tonight about the consequences for 1982. Every university and every college of advanced education is now faced with the dilemma of how to budget for the rest of the year, knowing that somewhere, somehow, it will have to meet the cost, collectively, of the $75m extra as a result of the Academic Salaries Tribunal decision.

I would be perfectly happy to accept from the Minister an undertaking that at an appropriate time he will provide compensation for universities and colleges for the effect of this increase. I realise that currently a national wage case is under way. The decision of that national wage case is not yet known. It will have implications for universities and colleges and I accept the fact that the Minister ought to take that decision into account before finalising his review of this matter. I do say to the Minister that tonight, as perhaps his final gesture of goodwill-if he can find such a gesture in his heart-he ought to give that undertaking to universities and colleges to provide compensation in respect of those salary and wage increases.

It is not enough for the Minister to say that allowance for these increases has already been built into the grants for 1982 and beyond. In the absence of his indicating the basis of that calculation no one can possibly be expected to believe that adequate provision has been made for the increases which have just been announced.

The other and particularly substantive matter which is included in this group of Bills is the further attempt by the Government to reintroduce tertiary fees. This subject has been debated endlessly in this House and pursued in another place. I do not intend to do anything more than to go over the very fundamental reasons for the Opposition's continued rejection of this proposal. In the first place, it represents a quite clear breach of a pre-election undertaking by the Minister that the Government had before it no proposal to reintroduce tertiary tuition fees. Any fair-minded Australian was entitled to take that as an undertaking that the Government would not reintroduce tertiary tuition fees. It was only a matter of months before that promise was breached with the report of the razor gang and the Government's intention to proceed in this way was revealed.

Secondly, what is clear from this proposal is that the Government is not simply interested in reintroducing tertiary tuition fees in the limited way indicated. I note that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) is here. We heard earlier from the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume). Also, the honourable member for Moore (Mr Hyde) has been very outspoken on these matters. They all believe that there should be a general application of tertiary tuition fees. Another 20 or 25 members of the Government also believe that should happen . This legislation is really about re-establishing the principle of tertiary tuition fees so that the fee collecting apparatus can be set up and at some time in the future rapidly extended to cater for the collection of fees from all undergraduate students as well as post-graduate students.

Thirdly, the imposition of fees for post-graduate students will undermine the already inadequate research effort and will reduce the supply of trained research workers for business, government and higher education itself. We already know that post-graduate students are an integral part of the research effort, in universities particularly. If the Government begins to select them for special penalties it will have a savage effect on the research effort of those universities-at a time when we ought to be encouraging research. Indeed, this debate provides an opportunity to discuss the report of the Commonwealth Research Centres of Excellence Committee. Thus, on the one hand the government is attempting to promote research in universities and, on the other, is trying to penalise the very students who are an integral part of that research effort.

My fourth point is that these fees really do represent the imposition of a thoroughly unfair penalty on post-graduate students who have already been hard hit by an inadequacy of financial assistance. I realise that under this proposal those who hold post-graduate awards would not have to pay a fee. Why should they, who enjoy no public support, be singled out for the extra penalty of having to pay fees? What we really need is not a fee to penalise post-graduate students, to compromise our research effort, but rather policies to regenerate that effort and provide the sort of encouragement that might lead to some form of economic regeneration in this country-regeneration of a kind that can only originate with some fairly imaginative research, amongst other things.

The other matter with which this package of Bills proposes to deal is the closure of colleges of advanced education. TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I express my disappointment that a debate on tertiary education is to last for an hour. This indicates the tone of education debates in this House in the last five years. This rests fairly and squarely with the Government because, as I will show in a few moments, there is no excuse for the Federal Government withdrawing from the Tertiary education field. The Government has been in that field for over 40 years and has accepted greater responsibilities than it accepts now. That its funding is inadequate can be easily shown from an article which appeared in the Age on Tuesday, 27 April. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Melbourne's three universities would face a combined deficit of about $7 million . . .

What does this mean in practical terms? It means that research projects are cut- research projects which will already be affected by the fees to be charged to post-graduate students. Not only will post-graduate students be unable to take part in research; there will be fewer research projects for them to take part in . What happens to development and to the other programs that are innovative? The professor of computer science in South Australia said recently that there is such a drain on tutorial staff in that area that-I think this is the term he used-we are swallowing the seed core. Institutions cannot train adequately those people who are needed in the outside world because the very people who can train them have been taken out to work in those areas. Staff levels are cut. Do not tell me that staff levels do not affect the training of the students.
What is tertiary education about? What are we looking for in this country? I quote a statement by my colleague Senator Button some time ago. He said:

So much of the future of Australia is dependent upon this nation developing a skilled workforce and a well educated population that there must be a commitment to a continual widening of access to tertiary and post-secondary education. Ultimately, the debate about education expenditure is one about freedom and equality-about choice and options for the majority of Australians. We can narrow the range of options and choice to a limited and fortunate few-options in terms of job opportunities, self-fulfilment and leisure, or we can constantly strive to make these options available to all Australians.

Of course, this Government is about the first option of restricting it to a fortunate few. The Federal Government historically has been involved in tertiary education for 40 years. In 1942 the Universities Commision was set up. In 1945 the Commonwealth Office of Education, to agree on grants with the States, was set up. In 1943 students in reserve faculties at universities had their fees paid and had a means tested living allowance and an incidentals allowance. This was extended to students in other faculties at the end of the war. The Commonwealth Reconstruction Training Scheme originated in 1944 and allowed many other people to enter university. These initiatives were supposed to produce some equality of opportunity and to change the types of people who were able to enter university. Admittedly, in 1951, the Commonwealth Scholarships Scheme replaced the other scheme and led to basic inequality. Then, under the Whitlam Government, we had the abolition of university fees and the introduction of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance. It was hoped that these steps would give a wider spread of students entering universities from across the socio-economic groups. Unfortunately, this did not happen. I quote from Anderson and others in Students in Australian Higher Education, produced in 1980. It states:

We have seen that the social composition of students in higher education has been relatively stable over several decades despite the changes which have taken place during that time: changes which have seen a great expansion of universities and colleges, a rise in retention rate to 12th year in secondary school, a growth in general affluence of the population and the introduction of many egalitarian measures. There is still much social inequality and economic hardship in society but its roots are deep in the social fabric; and it would be unlikely that a simple change at one particular point in the system, such as the abolition of fees, would have any great effects on the social composition of students in higher education. Most of the socially handicapping circumstances have had their effect well before students even get to the point of seeking a place in higher education.

That very matter was discussed in the debate which preceded the discussion of this legislation. The main cause goes back to social and economic circumstances, back to primary and secondary schooling. But this Government continues this disadvantage into the tertiary years. Vice-Chancellor Low, in his final report to the Australian National University, when speaking about the cuts, stated:
To revert to a term I employed late in 1980: the wolf has now eaten a very large meal inside the door, and the gore from his gnashings is splashed all about us.

He went on to point out that the maximum level of allowance under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme for those who are living away from home dropped between 1974 and 1981 by $160. While in 1973-4 that allowance was 21 per cent of the average weekly earnings, now it is more than 10 per cent less that the maximum weekly rate of unemployment benefit. He pointed out that the disadvantage was not only to students but also to the ANU, which in the previous year had lost 67 staff positions-a reduction of 8.5 per cent of academic positions and 8.85 per cent of general staff. This is reflected in other tertiary institutions. One knows the sad effect this has on services to students . Reverting to the TEAS allowance, we find that in 1980 only 35.3 per cent of students were receiving any sort of allowance. Yet in 1968, under the old schemes, well over 50 per cent of students received assistance.

There is a decline in the number of people who are entering tertiary education. According to the Tertiary Education Commission, there is a decline of about one- fifth. What is worse is the elitism which is being introduced in this way. A recent analysis suggests that the offspring of parents in professional and managerial occupations outnumber by three to one children of skilled and manual workers. Disadvantage is piled on disadvantage. Children of skilled and manual workers are disadvantaged by social and economic circumstances. They are disadvantaged by the provision of the type of primary and secondary education. If they eventually aspire to tertiary education, they are the ones who cannot use it because of the restrictions that this Government is placing on the assistance and, indeed, on the services available to them.

We are told by this Government that an obvious way to help students is by a loan scheme. Apart from Government members, I have not heard anyone support the concept of a student loan scheme. The universities know that it will be too costly to administer and that the strain on the university graduates in the way of repayments will be too much. After all, not all of those completing tertiary education receive massive incomes as a result of that education. It gives them the opportunity to go into jobs which are interesting to them in certain disciplines. It does not necessarily provide them with large rewards. Those people in the group for whom we are trying to produce equality will be the ones least able, then they finally start working, to repay heavy loans. It would be less expensive for the Government to review that allowance and bring it up to a value that would enable youngsters from the poorer socio-economic areas to go through the tertiary process without disadvantage.

We know that there are more adult and part time students now because young people simply cannot afford to undertake full time tertiary education. We know that the numbers of applications are declining. The cutoff marks for admission to faculties are getting lower. I would like to know what the dropout rate is this year between the commencement of terms. I was talking to a university student who was supposed to do a group project last week with three other students in sociology. When they came to get together for the team project she found that the other members of her team had dropped out from the university at this early stage. From my experience this would be due to economic circumstances . Not only is the allowance too low but also there is a lack of part time work for these youngsters that used to be available in the past.

Time is restricted in this debate. I said earlier that I was disappointed that the time available for education debates is persistently restricted. I think that is a shame. I believe that a number of members have a contribution to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have another eight minutes.

—No, I have not, because I have offered one of my colleagues some time in which to speak. We ought to be looking at education not only from the point of view of the tertiary level but also from the point of view of what disadvantages are happening down in the primary and secondary areas. We need to identify that educational disadvantage. If we truly believe this type of education ought to be available to all we should be doing something about it instead of, as this Government is doing, trying to insist that this type of education is for a few, for an elite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say I was most disappointed with the contribution from the honourable member of Mackellar (Mr Carlton). I did not think in the short time he had available that he did himself any credit by attacking the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins). The States Grants ( Tertiary Education Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 provides additional funding for salary and wage increases related to the recurrent programs of universities, colleges of advanced education and tertiary and further education institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is not opposing this Bill because it is providing much needed funding, but I would like to take the opportunity to describe the serious deficiencies which are occurring in the colleges of advanced education in Victoria. These deficiencies are, of course, reflected in colleges of advanced education all over Australia. But I will restrict my comments in this speech to the disastrous effects of educational policies of both the previous Liberal State Government of Victoria and the present Liberal-National Country Party Federal Government on the needs of Victoria. Fortunately, with a State Labor Government in Victoria committed to revitalising and expanding tertiary education in that State we can confidently expect some alleviation of the present deplorable situation.

However, too much cannot be expected of the State Labor Government as it will be hamstrung by the continuing deleterious effect of the Federal Government's razor gang recommendations. These recommendations, which were a supposed attempt to achieve some rationalisation and diversification of resources among the colleges, have in fact been a device to restrict further the funding available to the colleges. The consolidation of the colleges has, as was intended by the Federal Government, resulted in a reduction in the total number of college places and thus in student access to college education. Staff-student ratios, the total funding per student, the availability of places for female school leavers, migrants and low income earners have all been drastically reduced.

In Victoria the approved intakes for pre-service teacher training in 1984 will be 50 per cent less than in 1975 and 17 per cent less than in 1981. This planned reduction represents a reduction from 6,581 commencing students in 1975 to 3,880 commencing students in 1981 to a mere 3,220 in 1984. Such a reduction and the method of implementation-a forced marriage between relatively desparate institutions-is disastrous for the future of Victorian education. The United Kingdom is at present suffering the results of similar ill-advised cutbacks in teacher education which occurred in the early 1970s and which has resulted in an acute shortage of mathematics, science, English, foreign language and industrial arts teachers. In fact, in Victoria, we are already suffering teacher shortages in mathematics, sciences, English, languages, music, geography and craft subject areas. There is no denying that there was an over-supply of teachers in the late 1970s but this should not have been used as an excuse to cut back teacher education at a time when the Australian population requires educating to cope with periods of ever increasing leisure. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission projections of teacher supply and demand have been seriously questioned by a number of professional educationalists. The TEC's assumptions about teacher training completion rates, population statistics, teacher wastage rates and pupil-teacher ratios have been criticised and a number of errors and uncertainties indicated.

In view of the vital importance of the TEC's forecasts of future teacher needs, it is important to draw attention to the five major areas where there are uncertain, if not faulty, assumptions. Firstly, the TEC has estimated that teacher loss rates will rise by 0.2 per cent per year from a level of 5 per cent in 1979. But the teacher loss rate in Victorian government schools was frequently double this figure; it ranged from 8.2 per cent to 9.6 per cent over the period 1970-77. Only in 1978-79 was there a sudden drop to 5 per cent, but in 1980 the figure rose again to 5.7 per cent. Even higher loss rates were registered with 22.5 per cent amongst temporary government teachers and 17.5 per cent amongst Catholic school teachers.

Secondly, the TEC has assumed that there will be an annual migration rate of 50 ,000 persons. But during 1980 the figure was 93,000 and is estimated to reach 120,000 in 1981. There is no reason to believe that this doubling of the migration rate will not continue into the future. Therefore, the TEC has underestimated school enrolments in relation to migration rates by 1.5 per cent. Thirdly, in relation to birth and fertility rates, the TEC has based its projections on Australian Bureau of Statistics series A fertility projections despite the fact that these projections were exceeded in both 1978 and 1979. Primary enrolments may be dropping in the early 1980s but they will increase dramatically from 1987 onwards as the children who formed the post-war baby boom begin to have children of their own. The increase in the fertility rate obviously will result in an eventual increase in primary school enrolments leading to an increase in the demand for teachers. Fourthly, the increases in real recurrent funding for non-government schools is likely to lead to improved staff-student ratios but the TEC has not taken account of the possibility of an increasing demand for teachers as a result of this factor.

Finally, there is the availability of new graduates for teaching. Not all teaching college graduates choose to teach and the TEC has assumed that 10 per cent will go into non-teaching fields. However, surveys by the Graduate Careers Council of Australia have shown that 20 per cent of new teacher college graduates do not enter the teaching field. Thus the TEC has overestimated the supply of new teacher graduates by 10 per cent. Of course, it is argued that the criticisms of the TEC forecast of future teacher needs which are based on a research paper by Dr Gerald Burke of the Faculty of Education at Monash University are not valid in Victoria because the research paper is related to national trends. I find this argument completely specious as it is impossible to argue that the criticisms bear no relation to Victoria and the total effect of the faulty assumptions is a gross underestimate of the number of teachers required in Victoria from the middle 1980s onwards. It is impossible not to conclude that the cuts to teacher education and the so-called rationalisation of colleges of advanced education were done solely for political expediency rather than to meet the actual educational needs of the Australian people.

I would like to turn now to another aspect of the cutbacks in funding for colleges of advanced education which I have not had the opportunity to discuss in previous debates but which is becoming a matter for great concern at present. During the past 20 years the participation of women in tertiary education has increased dramatically. But with the increasing implementation of the razor gang cuts-I suppose I should use that body's proper name; the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions-the participation of women in the advanced education sector has been seriously curtailed. The ad hoc policies of the razor gang have placed in jeopardy the chances of women obtaining a college education, their opportunities of gaining college academic or administrative employment and their career prospects if they are already employed as a member of the academic staff. Female CAE enrolments increased from 45.3 per cent in 1975 to 48.8 per cent of all enrolments in 1980 in Australia as a whole. The TEC, in its 1982-84 triennium report, argued that the decline in teacher education places over the 1979-80 period did not entail a loss of opportunities for female students as there were compensating increases of female enrolments in other fields of study. The studies listed were applied science, business studies, paramedical and liberal studies. The report implied that cuts in teacher education would not disadvantage women students unable to gain entry into teacher education courses. But 70 per cent of teacher education enrolments are female and as the cuts amounted to 10,500 places over the 1979-84 period this means that the number of female students expected to transfer to other courses during that period was in the order of 7,000.

The evidence is that a limit has already been reached in the number of female school leavers, many of whom lack the mathematics-science prerequisites, who can be absorbed in other fields of study. At the same time, they would find it difficult to enter liberal studies courses because the TEC has expressly refused to increase enrolments in those courses. In fact, the enrolments will be cut by 13 per cent over the triennium. Similarly, art and design, another area of study preferred by female students, will also be cut over the triennium by 8 per cent. So, combined with the 15 per cent cut in teacher education places, for every four places being abolished in traditional female areas of study, only one new place is being created in other female areas of study favoured by female students, namely, paramedical studies. The cuts in teacher education, liberal studies, art and design means that thousands of female school leavers and mature age women seeking retraining have nowhere to go in their search for higher education and the retrograde policies of the present Federal Government entail enormous hidden costs to the community in terms of wasted female abilities.

I should like to continue to detail how the razor gang cuts are threatening the future careers of the women college staff but time is against me. The four aspects of discrimination against women in staffing appointments should be noted as follows: Firstly, women are greatly under-represented in college academic staffs; secondly, disproportionately large number of women staff do not have permanently-tenured positions as compared with male staff; thirdly, male staff continue to occupy most of the senior academic and administrative positions in colleges; and, finally, women staff are disproportionately concentrated in traditional areas of study, such as teacher education, liberal studies and paramedical studies.
I quote now from the comments of the Council of Academic Staff Associations in Victorian Colleges of Advanced Education on this matter. It states:
The first three findings-
I have just quoted them-

point to possible discrimination at the point of entry into colleges or in granting of promotion, tenure and study leave, as well as to historical circumstances that have made it difficult for women to gain the qualifications sought for many academic positions.

The fourth finding, coupled with their insecurity of tenure, means that women college staff will be especially threatened by Razor Gang cuts to teacher education and liberal studies. All the gains that women have made in gaining access to academic careers may soon be vitiated if planned cutbacks go ahead.

Whilst the Opposition is not opposing this Bill, I take this opportunity to condemn the Federal Government for its retrograde education policies which are causing a dramatic decline in the quality of tertiary education in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I propose to ignore completely the personalities entered into by the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) when he should have been addressing this Bill and to concentrate my address in reply on the very important issues concerning tertiary education in Australia that are before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: This cognate debate, which I hasten to add is one of the many wide ranging education debates which have taken place in this House over the past 2 1/2 years , covers Bills to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1981 and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1978 in order to provide adjustments to grants for cost increases. It also concerns aspects of the Government's decisions on the consolidation of colleges of advanced education as well as the limited re-introduction of tuition fees for second and higher qualifications. The debate has covered proposed amendments to the Australian National University Act 1945 and the Canberra College of Advanced Education Act 1967 so as to enable the limited re-introduction of tuition fees at those two institutions. In addition, the report of the Commonwealth Research Centres of Excellence Committee has also been brought to the attention of honourable members.

It continues to be the Government's view that those who wish to further their studies beyond a reasonable range of basic qualifications should make a contribution towards the cost of tuition. There are substantial benefits which flow to individuals from higher education and the Government believes that the community as a whole should not be expected to meet all of the costs. The Government is clearly opposed to the restoration of tuition fees for first degree or first diploma qualifications. In fact, the legislation continues the provision which has existed for some time preventing tertiary institutions from charging tuition fees to students undertaking first degrees and diplomas.

I turn now to the further implementation of the Government's policy of rationalisation in higher education. Arising from the Government's Review of Commonwealth Functions, it was decided that 30 colleges of advanced education should be consolidated into larger institutions or should amalgamate with nearby institutions. At this stage, only six of the original 30 have not yet entered into acceptable consolidation arrangements. The Wollongong Institute of Education is now to become part of the new consolidated institution in that city . It is not true, as stated by the honourable member for Fremantle, that the Government has closed down 30 colleges of advanced education. They have been or will be consolidated. I emphasise that the colleges have not been closed down.

The amending legislation before the House provides funds this year for the six institutions not yet consolidated. However, these funds are being provided on the clear understanding that negotiations aimed at achieving consolidation will be actively pursued with a view to acceptable arrangements being reached before the end of 1982. Should such consolidation arrangements not be achieved, the Government will not be prepared to continue to provide recurrent funds for the institutions concerned. It is the Government's intention that the consolidation of resources should enable advanced education to be more responsive to changes in demand for various types of courses and to enable the resources available for advanced education to be used as effectively as possible. I take this opportunity to remind honourable members that although the Government is committed to a policy of economic restraint, total funds provided for tertiary education for 1982 have been increased marginally, in real terms. This of course is contrary to what the honourable member for Fremantle would have the House believe.

As I explained in my statement of 4 June 1981 on guidelines for the programs administered by the Commission, the Government is maintaining its overall commitment to education as a priority area of direct Commonwealth endeavour. It is continuing to give priority to technical and further education. With this object in mind, funds for TAFE were increased for 1982 by nearly 6 per cent in real terms, and at the same time there was a small reduction in the funds provided for higher education-a reduction of less than one half of one per cent. In respect of recurrent funds for higher education, the Government has re- iterated its commitment to fixed triennial funding arrangements. The House needs to recall that it was the previous Labor Government which did away with fixed triennial funding arrangements for universities and colleges of advanced education. The Government has undertaken to maintain the 1982 funds in real terms over the 1982-84 triennium. Since that decision, honourable members will be aware that I have announced the provision of up to a further $12m for higher education during 1983 and 1984 to assist with the rising costs of staff superannuation schemes.

As I mentioned earlier, the legislation also makes provision for the further implementation of the Government's 1980 election undertakings. I refer, of course, to the introduction of community language courses and the establishment of research centres. Specifically, the legislation transfers certain of the funds set aside for these initiatives under the States grants legislation to enable funds to be provided for the Australian National University, whose funds are appropriated separately. In no way does this transfer reduce the total funds available; it is merely a machinery provision to enable funds to be allocated to the Australian National University for these particular purposes.

As I explained in my second reading speech, the amendments to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1978 will increase the 1980 and 1981 grants provided under that legislation in response to relevant cost movements that have occurred during those two years. It is anticipated that these increases, which will total $53.7m, will be the final adjustments to these grants. I remind honourable members that, as I announced last year, the Government's policy is that from 1982 cost adjustment procedures will be based on a prospective arrangement rather than the retrospective arrangements that have operated previously. As far as the 1982 prospective allowance for the tertiary sector is concerned, the Government has recognised the need created by the Academic Salaries Tribunal report to look again at the adequacy of the allowance. As that allowance is made up of a number of components, including provision for national wage case movements, the Government will review the situation in the light of the result of the present national wage case.

I now turn briefly to the matter of research. During the debate this evening the Opposition claimed that provision for research in Australia had declined. This, of course, is not true. It is something that members of the Opposition continually say. I will state the correct position. Total funds available-these are given in average 1982 cost levels-in 1973 for research were as follows: Australian National University $56.4m, and State universities $75.6m making a total of $132m. In 1980-I emphasise again that these are in constant prices-the Australian National University received $65.7m and State universities received $ 105.4m, making a total of $171.1m. That, of course, in percentage terms represents an increase of 30 per cent. That is a very significant increase in the period from 1973 to 1980. The number of research staff and students have increased from 14,646 in 1973 to 18,346 in 1980, an increase of approximately 25 per cent.

In January 1982 the Government, following its consideration of the report of the Commonwealth Research Centres of Excellence Committee chaired by Mr S. B. Myer, announced that it would provide $16m in the triennium 1982-84 to enable 10 Commonwealth special research centres to be established in seven Australian universities. Funding for the Commonwealth special research centres is an addition to substantially increased special research grants already provided in the legislation and will total $31.5m for the triennium. The concept of research centres of excellence for Australia was first proposed by the former Universities Commission. It has since been supported by both the Universities Council and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. There has also been support from the Australian Science and Technology Council and other expert bodies.

The Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment commented on national research issues and the utilisation and retention of highly skilled research manpower, and recommended that support be provided through special research grants to enable centres to be built up in universities . The Myer Committee, in its approach to selection, decided that funding should go to 'creating new centres around existing individuals or nuclei of research activity', rather than its nominating particular areas of desirable research and trying to attract reseachers into these fields. In accordance with its terms of reference, it had concentrated on funding a relatively small number of highly promising centres, rather than spreading the available funds more widely to cover a greater number of subject or geographical areas. The $16m for the centres is for the 1982-84 triennium, although centres will be supported for up to six years in the first instance. The Government is confident that this initiative will significantly increase the strength and quality of the national research and development effort in the selected fields and that it will assist Australia's contribution to international scholarship.
