TALK.START.PARA: —I have mentioned on a number of occasions in this House the appalling penny-pinching attitude of the Federal Government towards Australian pensioners. I should like to draw attention to the case of a constituent of mine, Mrs Iris Andersen, which underlines the miserly attitude of the Government, which refuses to adopt effective legislation to prevent the blatant tax avoidance at present being practised by wealthy people in this country. Mrs Andersen has advised me that her mother, Mrs Hilda Unsunk, aged 86, was in Coogee Hospital on 9 September 1981 when she received her pension cheque, which was dated 10 September although it was received and cashed on 9 September. At 8 p.m. on 9 September, Mrs Unsunk died suddenly in hospital. Mrs Andersen immediately notified the Department of Social Security and her mother's pension cheques stopped coming.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, to assist the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), do you think that we should get an extension for his arms or some glasses as he is having difficulty in reading?
—There is no point of order. The Minister does himself less than well to interject.

—The Minister can do better than that. I am disappointed by his comment. I should have thought that he would have realised that a matter such as this is much too important to call for the flippant remarks that he has just made. On 12 January Mrs Andersen received a letter from Social Security saying that she owed $126.30, the amount of the cheque issued on 10 September 1981. I understand that pension cheques are issued fortnightly on a set date, irrespective of the pensioner's eligibility date, and no doubt 10 September was the set date for the issuance of Mrs Unsunk's cheque. At Mrs Andersen's request, I wrote to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) about the matter and indicated that I could understand why his Department mailed the cheques before the pension date-to enable pensioners to have their cheques on a set date in case of postal delays-but that what I could not understand was a department that splits hairs so closely, since Mrs Unsunk died four hours before the issuance of the cheque. Mrs Andersen intends to pay the $126.30. But I asked for the Minister's comments on this case. He replied as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Services Act provides for pensions to be paid in fortnightly instalments calculated by dividing the annual rate by 26. Entitlements fall due each payday; payments are made neither in advance nor in arrears.

When an eligible person lodges a claim for pension, payment commences from the first pension payday after the date of lodgment, or from the date of lodgment if that was a pension payday. Thus, when a pension is granted there is no reduction in the first payment proportionate to the number of days between the date of eligibility and the first payday; nor is there any payment due for the period between the last payday and the date on which pension eligibility ceases. Therefore, if a pensioner has received payment for the pension payday prior to the date of death there is no further pension due.
While I can understand Mrs Andersen seeing this as an anomaly I can only confirm that as Mrs Unsunk died on 9 September 1981, no pension entitlement existed after 27 August 1981.

In my view the Minister's answer is most unsatisfactory because he has admitted in relation to this matter that there could be an anomaly in the administrative processes of his Department. I call on the Government to stop this inhumane practice and to refund the much needed amount of $126.30 to Mrs Andersen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the hour is late, so I will be brief. I wish to bring to the notice of the House a matter of concern to me and one which should be of concern to all members. It is an incident that happened during the Victorian State election in the electorate of Box Hill, which in part incorporates the Federal electorate of Deakin. An Independent candidate by the name of Peter J. Allan of Blackburn, Victoria, put out a how to vote card the same size and same colour-and with many similarities-as that of the card for the endorsed Liberal candidate. When I went to vote at 8 a.m. this card was handed to me and I took it, as did many other people, thinking it was the card of the endorsed Liberal candidate. The card used much the same wording, including the words 'Action for Box Hill'; the photograph was in the same position; there was a big 'vote', a very small 'independent' and a very large 'Liberal' printed in blue and white, the traditional Liberal colours. The card gave the effective second preference in both the Legislative Assembly seat and the Legislative Council seat to the Australian Labor Party. I do not believe that the Labor Party had any part in this subterfuge but in my view the card was deliberately set out by Mr Allan to mislead voters who wished to vote Liberal into voting Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: I immediately rang the Liberal Party State Director, proceeded to the city and took out in the Supreme Court a writ to stop distribution of the card. This was done with the consent of the Victorian Attorney-General having been obtained. Mr Justice King gave a verdict in my favour. Costs were awarded against the offending candidate, Mr Peter Allan, and he was ordered to withdraw his card from distribution. However, all this took time, and by the time Mr Allan was prevented by Mr Justice King's decision from handing out these cards it was 1.30 p.m. and many, if not most, of the people would have voted by that time and no doubt would have been misled into voting in a way other than that of their choice.

I suggest that the Commonwealth Electoral Act should be altered so that every candidate must lodge his how to vote card with the returning oficer at least three days in advance and that these cards should be open to inspection by the public, including other candidates. This would mean that it would be possible in situations such as this one for action to be taken in time to stop the distribution of misleading cards at any time on polling day. No other cards should be allowed to be distributed outside polling booths. I believe that the Electoral Act should be changed, and certainly it is in our power in the Federal sphere to do so. I am writing to the Minister concerned to see what can be done to stop this mischievous misleading of well-intentioned voters on polling day. The alternative of course is showing endorsed candidates' party affiliations on the ballot paper. Mr Peter Allan is to be condemned as a mischievous, misleading candidate. I ask leave to incorporate in Hansard the two cards concerned and the relevant legal document. I have already shown them to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise on the adjournment the continuing attitude of this Government in its foreign policy relations with the United States as a government which sees itself as a partner of the United States in being prepared so readily to acquiesce in the continuing human rights atrocities which are being committed in El Salvador by the armed forces of that country, forces which are being trained and armed by the Government of the United States. I refer the House to the most recent report of Amnesty International, which spent some considerable time examining the evidence on human rights abuses in El Salvador. As a result of that examination it reached the following conclusions:

SPEECH.PARA: Amnesty International is aware that these human rights violations are occurring at a time of civil conflict between guerilla groups and the Salvadorean authorities. It is also aware of reports of abuses having been committed by non- governmental forces. After careful study of all available information, Amnesty International has concluded that the great majority of the reported violations, including torture, disappearances and cold-blooded murder, have been carried out by the security forces and have been directed against non-combatant civilians not involved in guerrilla activities.

The accompanying document to the report is really horrific in its contents. I do not propose to take up the time of the House by reading out gruesome extracts. It is sufficient to say that almost every kind of human rights abuse which can be named and documented has been named and documented. These abuses are not committed in the heat of battle by competing military forces, be they guerrilla or army forces. The importance of this report is that it highlights a continuing abuse against a non-combatant civilian population which is unable to protect itself. I will quote from sections of a report made by United States Congressman , Patricia Schroeder, who testified to a congressional committee, having visited El Salvador as part of a congressional group. She said she had collected evidence suggesting that the pattern of atrocities carried out by the official security and armed forces continued as before. She told the congressional committee that the Salvadorean Government soldiers would routinely round up, shoot, bayonet, dismember and disembowel their own civilian population. She stated:

As a member of our delegation I asked Salvadorean military officials who was responsible for these grotesque mutilations. He casually told us that his men were responsible and that it was simply a way of terrifying the Salvadorean people so they would not have contact with anyone other than the army. These are civilians whose bodies are dragged into the middle of town as a warning to others.

Before the United States Senate hearings in testimony in 1981-this is also referred to by the Amnesty International report-Richard Millett, Professor of History at Southern Illinois University, Edwardsville, Illinois, who was called to testify as an expert witness, stated that in 1980 President Duarte had said:

For fifty years the army has been trained to act as a repressive instrument, a force of terror. The army has been taught to understand that anyone opposed to their way of thinking is a communist. They have been naturally taught to do what comes naturally to them-get rid of communists.

I am concerned that these gross and wilful abuses of human rights continue, although this issue has been raised in the Parliament, with the connivance and permission of this Government. They have been brought to the attention of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Foreign Minister (Mr Street). It seems to me that if Australia sees itself as having a relationship with the United States-and we do; we see ourselves as part of the military alliance- surely it behoves an Australian government that says it has a commitment to human rights to say to the United States Government: 'You must cease the provision of military arms and training to the El Salvadorean military establishment which is involved in these gross violations or else you have to accept the moral opprobrium of Australia and nations of the Western world who are committed to the establishment of human rights wherever they may be. This Government has a very selective view of human rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to take up the time of the House at this very late hour but I suppose it is never too late to once again bring to the attention of the House and the people of the country the cynical actions taken by this Government. One of the most cynical actions, in the wake of the Review of Commonwealth Functions last year, was the decision to axe the collection and publication of the Commonwealth Employment Service statistics of the number of persons registered as unemployed and the number of unfilled job vacancies. This action, demonstrating the Government's callous lack of concern for the unemployed, can be construed only as an attempt to lose the victims of its economic policies, to hide them from view.

SPEECH.PARA: The only information available to us on the extent of the problem of unemployment comes from the Bureau of Statistics monthly estimates. This ABS monthly estimate is based on a sample survey in each State, and as such can be used to look only at broad trends. Without the CES statistics no measure is available to us of local and regional employment patterns. That this is so is causing concern to many people in my electorate, where a number of worthwhile initiatives are being undertaken by organisations to deal with the current high level of unemployment. These include looking at ways of developing new job opportunities though community action and the provision of support services to those unfortunate citizens who face the prospect of long-term unemployment. We recognise that these fall into all age groups and that each age group has its own particular problems.

As a result of the Government's penny-pinching razor gang the necessary planning for these activities is being hindered by the lack of current local statistical information. What use is it to Ballarat people to know the ABS estimate of unemployment in Victoria. Until the CES figures were abolished the unemployment rate in the cities and towns of my electorate had been indicated to be far above the overall Victorian rate. There has been no evidence to suggest that the situation has improved in this last year. There can be no doubt that this has been a source of great embarrassment to the Fraser Government. So rather than introduce policies which would have the effect of creating new job opportunities, it was much easier for the Government to abandon, in very cynical fashion the collection and publication of regional unemployment statistics; in other words sweep the problem under the carpet. Under the guise of a cost-saving measure this action exposes the moral bankruptcy of a government which is doing nothing to assist those in my community who are making valiant attempts to ease the plight of the victims of the Government's savage economic policies. If the Government has even a modicum of concern for these people, I implore it to reverse its decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1633) Dr Theophanous asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, a question without notice concerning the accuracy of crude oil excise payments. I undertook to obtain an answer to the honourable member's question.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for National Development and Energy has now provided the following information:

The 190th report of the Public Accounts Committee did not state that 'up to $ 100 million was lost in revenue not collected from Bass Strait companies'. Paragraph 6.22 of the report includes the sentence:

'While the Committee believes that well-stream flows are accurately metered, evidence was received that the probable error in collection of excise in 1978- 79 due to the inaccuracy of the back allocation procedures would exceed plus or minus $10 million.'
This is the only reference in that report to the potential for a loss in excise revenue. It should be noted that the inaccuracies referred to can lead to either losses or gains in revenue.

The comment by the Public Accounts Committee, and conclusions drawn by Dr Theophanous is speculative: there is no evidence to suggest that the procedures followed by the licensees have resulted in significant over or under payments of excise or royalty.
The difficulties surrounding the measurement of stabilised crude oil production on a field by field basis are outlined in paragraphs 6.2 to 6.6 of the report.

The Commonwealth engaged an international firm of consultants to examine the sampling procedures, to report on the controls within the system, and to recommend any changes considered necessary to ensure the accuracy of the results obtained. The consultants concluded that the procedures and standards used by Esso Australia Limited for petroleum accounting purposes in regard to the calculation of royalty and excise are carried out in accordance with accepted international standards and procedures.

The Federal Government relies on the effectiveness of the measurement and sampling procedures maintained by Esso Australia Limited, over which Victorian Government officials exercise a surveillance role. The Victorian Minister for Minerals and Energy is the Designated Authority under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. The allocation of production to producing fields is verified by the Department of National Development and Energy.
Since the report of the Public Accounts Committee was released last year, a number of developments have occurred:
(1) the report by the international firm of consultants (Gaffney Cline and Associates) referred to earlier has been received.

(2) the metering, the measurement standards and procedures used by the producers have been documented and submitted to the National Association of Testing Authorities (NATA) with a view to registration by that organisation. NATA is currently reviewing the procedures to see what changes, if any, may be required to meet registration requirements.
(3) A complete review of the producers' procedures and their documentation is being carried out by a working group comprising Commonwealth, State and company representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 17 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he considered introducing harsher penalties for companies or contractors responsible for oil spillages in Australian waters and ports.

(2) What is the (a) amount collected by the Government from fines on shipping companies for oil spillages and (b) cost to the Government for oil dispersal or containment actions over the last 3 years.
(3) Were any ships involved considered to be unseaworthy, derelict, or in need of repair.
(4) What are the present methods available to the Government for dispersing or containing huge oil spills.
(5) Are they the most modern and up to date methods in use throughout the world .
(6) Are the names of the ships, the method of dispersals and/or the quantity of oil often not reported; if so, why.
(7) Has the incidence of non-reportage of oil spill information increased in the last 3 years; if so why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The present maximum penalty under existing legislation is $50 000 but the Government considered this insufficient and the Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Act 1981 raises this penalty to $100 000. The Act will be introduced as soon as practicable, but does not, however, apply to areas within State or Northern Territory control. Responsibility for land-sourced oil pollution or ship-sourced spills within the three mile territorial sea and inland waters rests with the States and Northern Territory.

(2) (a) Fines have not been collected by the Commonwealth Government as to date all major spills from a known source have occurred in areas under State or Northern Territory control and legal proceedings have been instituted by the State concerned.

(b) A total of $372,490.44 has been paid by the Government over the past three years for oil containment and dispersal action. Of this amount $173,182.30 has been recovered from known polluters. $149,266.47 is in the process of being recovered and $50,041.67 is not recoverable as the source of the marine pollution was not known.
(3) My Department has received no information that any ships involved were considered to be unseaworthy, derelict, or in need of repair.

(4) Methods available in Australia to handle any envisaged oil spill include containment by booms, recovery of oil by the use of oil recovery vessels and skimmers, use of various types of absorbents to mop up oil from affected areas and break-up of oil by the use of dispersants. The dispersant is applied from vessels using approved spraying equipment. The use of aircraft to apply dispersant is under investigation. Barges and other temporary storage vessels for the removal of oily wastes from the oil recovery units are obtained from local sources as necessary. Internationally, specialists are agreed that no known equipment can adequately handle a huge spill such as that which occurred from the Amoco Cadiz.

(5) These methods are similiar to those in use in other parts of the world. Australian marine pollution specialists have attended the leading international training courses and seminars on oil pollution control and are constantly monitoring and evaluating overseas practices.
(6) Not to my knowledge. My information is that all known spills are reported to the appropriate authority.
(7) I have no reason to believe that there has been any increase in non- reporting of oil spills in the past three years.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 25 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does sub-paragraph 25 (2) (b) (i) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act provide that a redistribution may be made whenever in one-fourth of the Divisions of the State the number of electors differs from a quota ascertained in accordance with that part of the Act to a greater extent than one-tenth more or one-tenth less.
(2) In how many Divisions in the State of Queensland do the number of electors differ from the quota to a greater extent than one-tenth more or one-tenth less.
(3) Do they together comprise in excess of one-fourth of the Divisions of the State.
(4) Do projected representation entitlements of the States indicate that Queensland would not be entitled to an increase in the number of Divisions until after 2005 A.D.

(5) Does paragraph 25 (2) (a) provide that a proclamation, for the purposes of a redistribution, shall be made where a State entitlement to an increase or decrease in the number of Members of the House of Representatives is determined.

(6) Will the State of Queensland have to wait until this section applies sometime next century before a redistribution occurs, or will the Government give consideration to a redistribution if or when the conditions of sub- paragraph 25 (2) (b) (i) apply.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Enrolments in seven Queensland Divisions differ from the State average enrolment to a greater extent than one-tenth more or one-tenth less.
(3) Yes.

(4) I am informed that the latest population projections which are available from the Australian Bureau of Statistics are based on data initially derived from the 1976 Census. I have further been informed that the Australian Bureau of Statistics hopes to publish in July of this year population Projections based on data from the 1981 Census. These latter projections would provide an up to date basis on which projections as to the future representation entitlements of the States could be made. In the absence of these new population projections I would not wish now to comment on future representation entitlements.
(5) Yes.

(6) In respect of a non-mandatory redistribution as a consequence of the conditions as set in sub-paragraph 25 (2) (b) (i) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, the wording of the Act is perfectly clear in that it indicates that given the existence of those particular circumstances a redistribution may be undertaken. There is no requirement to do so and the law does not envisage that a redistribution in those circumstances is mandatory or necessarily warranted. The question is one for Government consideration and is not one on which I would wish to comment.
